revision.text:
{{Primary sources|date=January 2010}} The '''Bellagio Declaration''' is a [[Resolution (law)|resolution]] formed in 1993, with the aim of reforming [[intellectual property law]]s in order to foster the protection of [[Folklore|folkloric works]], works of [[cultural heritage]], and the biological and ecological [[know-how]] of traditional peoples.
It was from the 1993 Rockefeller Conference "Cultural Agency/Cultural Authority: Politics and Poetics of Intellectual Property in the Post-Colonial Era".
== External links == * [http://www.cwru.edu/affil/sce/BellagioDec.html Text of Declaration]
[[Category:Intellectual property law]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2014}} {{DISPLAYTITLE:''Better Out Than In''}} {{Infobox event | title = ''Better Out Than In'' | image = Banksy Better Out Than In New York City 2013.png | image_size = | caption = Promotional poster | date = {{start date|df=yes|2013|10}} | place = [[New York City]] | coordinates = <!-- {{coord|40|43|N|74|0|W|region:US-NY|display=inline,title}} --> | also known as = | participants = [[Banksy]] | reported property damage = | inquiries = | inquest = | suspects = | accused = | convicted = | charges = | verdict = | convictions = | publication bans = | litigation = | awards = | url = | type = Artist residency | website = {{URL|banksy.co.uk}} | notes = }}
'''''Better Out Than In''''' was a residency undertaken by [[pseudonym]]ous [[graffiti artist]] and political activist [[Banksy]] in [[New York City]] during October 2013. Banksy unveiled at least one work of art daily, documenting it on both a dedicated website and an [[Instagram]] account. The majority of the works were [[stencil graffiti]] and chiefly political, a distinctive characteristic of Banksy. Other pieces and multimedia exhibits toyed with [[dark humor]] and [[Political satire|satire]].
The unpredictability of the show and Banksy's elusive nature stirred excitement amongst fans, while [[Defacement (vandalism)|defacement]] from competing street artists and vandals became an imminent problem. While Banksy's works were inherently illegal, no official complaints were reported to the police; most property owners praised the art and some took measures to protect it. The month-long residency drew controversy amongst some locals for its more politically strong pieces, and received mixed reviews from critics.
An HBO documentary film covering this period and residency titled ''[[Banksy Does New York]]'' was released in 2014.
==Background== On 1 October 2013, Banksy announced on his website that he would be attempting to host a show in New York City for the entire month. This came after posters promoting an October event started showing up in [[Los Angeles]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Vankin|first=Deborah|title=Banksy show to take place in New York -- but where is Banksy now?|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/arts/culture/la-et-cm-banksy-chinatown-but-where-is-banksy-now20131001,0,6799862.story|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|accessdate=21 October 2013|date=1 October 2013}}</ref><ref name=nytimes_announcement>{{cite news|last=Ryzik|first=Melena|title=Banksy Announces a Monthlong Show on the Streets of New York|url=http://artsbeat.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/10/01/banksy-announces-a-monthlong-show-on-the-streets-of-new-york/|work=[[New York Times]]|accessdate=21 October 2013|date=1 October 2013}}</ref>
The title ''Better Out Than In'' is a reference to a quote by [[impressionist]] [[Paul Cézanne]], "All pictures painted inside, in the studio, will never be as good as those done outside."<ref name=cbs_lookout>{{cite web|title=New Yorkers On The Lookout For Banksy Street Art Creations|url=http://newyork.cbslocal.com/2013/10/06/new-yorkers-on-the-lookout-for-banksy-street-art-creations/|work=[[CBS News]]|accessdate=21 October 2013}}</ref>
In an interview with ''[[The Village Voice]]'', Banksy said "New York calls to graffiti writers like a dirty old lighthouse. We all want to prove ourselves here," and that he chose it for the high foot traffic and hiding places.<ref name=village_interview>{{cite web|last=Hamilton|first=Keegan|title=Village Voice Exclusive: An Interview With Banksy, Street Art Cult Hero, International Man of Mystery|url=http://www.villagevoice.com/2013-10-09/art/banksy-better-out-than-in-new-york-residency-street-art-graffiti/full/|work=[[The Village Voice]]|accessdate=21 October 2013}}</ref>
==Works== [[File:Banksy 15 October installment in Better Out Than In New York City residency.jpg|thumb|right|Flowers left in [[TriBeCa]] at Banksy's depiction of the former [[World Trade Center (1973-2001)|World Trade Center]]]]
The works Banksy has included in ''Better Out Than In'' primarily consist of [[stencil graffiti]], much of which are political in nature. His first installment, which he captioned "the street is in play", depicted a child reaching for a bottle of spray paint on a sign reading "graffiti is a crime".<ref name=usnews>{{cite web|last=Sneed|first=Tierney|title=So How Is Banksy's New York Street Art Spree Going?|url=https://www.usnews.com/news/articles/2013/10/08/so-how-is-banksys-new-york-street-art-spree-going|work=[[U.S. News & World Report]]|accessdate=20 October 2013}}</ref> The sign was stolen and later replaced by [[Queens]]-based graffiti group [[Smart Crew]] with a new sign that read "street art is a crime".<ref>{{cite web|last=Chung|first=Jen|title=Smart Crew Sorta Recreated Banksy's Stencil After Sign Was "Stolen"|url=http://gothamist.com/2013/10/02/smart_crew_sorta_recreated_banksys.php#photo-2|work=[[Gothamist]]|accessdate=20 October 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131005000804/http://gothamist.com/2013/10/02/smart_crew_sorta_recreated_banksys.php#photo-2|archivedate=5 October 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Like most of his other works, the piece has audio accompaniment that can be heard either on the website or by calling a toll-free 800 number.<ref name=nydaily_les>{{cite news|last=Stebner|first=Beth|title=Street artist Banksy gets political in latest Lower East Side work|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/new-york/banksy-political-latest-les-work-article-1.1480889|work=[[New York Daily News]]|accessdate=20 October 2013}}</ref>
In the [[East Village, Manhattan|East Village]], Banksy's fifth work was housed in a delivery truck as a "mobile garden," which included [[theatrical property]] showing a rainbow, waterfall, and butterflies. The following day Banksy posted a photo of a tracking device he found under the vehicle.<ref>{{cite web|last=Li|first=Shirley|title=Banksy watch: The street artist's latest works -- and defacements|url=http://popwatch.ew.com/2013/10/11/banksy-street-art-new-york-tour/|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|accessdate=20 October 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Zeveloff|first=Julie|title=Banksy's 5th Work In New York Will Be A 'Mobile Waterfall' Inside A Delivery Truck|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/banksy-garden-inside-a-delivery-truck-2013-10|work=[[Business Insider]]|accessdate=20 October 2013}}</ref>
Banksy's installments are located all across the [[Borough (New York City)|five boroughs]], with some being purely [[Multimedia art|multimedia exhibits]]. On 6 October, as a way to have made an installment in [[Dumbo, Brooklyn]], a primary arts district of the city, Banksy posted a video featuring the [[Walt Disney]] character [[Dumbo]] being shot down by [[Syrian]] rebels, the meaning behind which puzzled many.<ref>{{cite news|last=Dunning|first=Jennifer|title=Banksy kills Dumbo in new video showing Syrian rebels shooting down elephant|url=http://www.cbc.ca/newsblogs/yourcommunity/2013/10/banksy-kills-dumbo-in-new-video-showing-syrian-rebels-shooting-down-elephant.html|work=CBC News|accessdate=21 October 2013}}</ref>
[[File:"Hammer Boy" Banksy in Upper West Side October 2013.jpg|thumb|left|''Hammer Boy'' was the 20th installment, located on the [[Upper West Side]]. Utilizing an existing [[siamese connection]] fire hydrant, it depicts a child playing a [[high striker]].]]
On 9 October, Banksy unveiled one of the more elaborate and politically strong pieces of the series. It featured armed soldiers and horses spray-painted on a car and trailer in an empty lot in the Lower East Side. Instead of commentary about the work, the accompanying audio was that of a classified video from the [[July 12, 2007 Baghdad airstrike]].<ref name="nydaily_les" /> After being dismantled, the car was towed away to prevent further defacement.<ref>{{cite web|last=Carlson|first=Jen|title=Photos: LES Banksy Car Has Been Towed To A Safe Place|url=http://gothamist.com/2013/10/15/photos_les_banksy_being_dismantled.php#photo-1|work=Gothamist|accessdate=20 October 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131018051843/http://gothamist.com/2013/10/15/photos_les_banksy_being_dismantled.php#photo-1|archivedate=18 October 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Day 11 saw an elaborate political display questioning the "casual cruelty" of the meat industry.<ref>{{cite news|last=Hubbard|first=Amy|title='Sirens of the Lambs': Banksy fills slaughterhouse truck with toys|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/arts/culture/la-et-cm-banksy-sirens-of-the-lambs-20131014,0,4832074.story|work=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=21 October 2013|date=14 October 2013}}</ref> Entitled ''Sirens of the Lambs'', Banksy drove around a military-style cargo truck filled with squealing, stuffed animatronic livestock.<ref>{{cite web|last=Brooks|first=Raillan|title=Banksy Day 11: A Truck Full of Very Loud Stuffed Animals In the Meatpacking District|url=http://blogs.villagevoice.com/runninscared/2013/10/banksy_day_11_sirens_of_the_lambs.php|work=[[The Village Voice]]|accessdate=21 October 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131015150158/http://blogs.villagevoice.com/runninscared/2013/10/banksy_day_11_sirens_of_the_lambs.php|archivedate=15 October 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The truck fittingly made its debut in [[Meatpacking District, Manhattan]], but toured the rest of the city in the following weeks.<ref>{{cite web|last=Zeveloff|first=Julie|title=Banksy Unleashes A Creepy Slaughterhouse Delivery Truck On The Meatpacking District|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/banksy-truck-filled-with-stuffed-animals-2013-10|work=Business Insider|accessdate=21 October 2013}}</ref>
On 13 October, Banksy made headlines when it was revealed that the art an older man was selling outside [[Central Park]] was actually authentic, signed Banksy canvases, sold for only $60 each.<ref name="nytimes_race">{{cite news|last=Barron|first=James|title=Racing to See Banksy Graffiti, While It Can Still Be See|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/10/16/nyregion/racing-to-see-banksy-graffiti-while-it-can-still-be-seen.html?_r=0|work=New York Times|accessdate=21 October 2013|date=15 October 2013}}</ref> Having not announced this beforehand, tourists and park goers were unaware of the value the paintings had, which the BBC estimated could be upwards of $32,000 each.<ref>{{cite news|title=Banksy stall sells art works for $60 in New York|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-24518315|work=[[BBC]]|accessdate=20 October 2013|date=14 October 2013}}</ref> Banksy posted a video on his website chronicling the surprise sale, which revealed that a total of seven paintings were sold for $420 taking.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Entertainment/wireStory/banksy-sold-original-artwork-60-nyc-20562101 |title=Banksy: I Sold Original Artwork for $60 in NYC - ABC News |publisher=[[ABC News]] |date= |accessdate=17 October 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2013/10/14/living/banksy-street-art-sale/?hpt=hp_c3 |title=Graffiti artist Banksy says he offered $60 paintings in Central Park - CNN.com |publisher=[[CNN]] |date=14 October 2013 |accessdate=17 October 2013}}</ref>
Banksy unveiled one of his most controversial pieces of the series on 15 October, with a depiction of the [[Lower Manhattan]] skyline featuring the former [[World Trade Center (1973-2001)|Twin Towers]], with a burnt-orange [[chrysanthemum]] in place where one of the hijacked airplanes struck the North Tower.<ref name=nytimes_race /><ref name=mirroruk>{{cite web|last=Evans|first=Natalie|title=Banksy in New York: Twin Towers graffiti with orange flower 'explosion' is latest controversial street art installation|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/world-news/banksy-new-york-twin-towers-2459315|work=Mirror News|accessdate=21 October 2013}}</ref> The silhouette appeared on the side of a building in [[TriBeCa]],<ref>{{cite web|last=Zeveloff|first=Julie|title=Banksy Pays Homage To The Twin Towers In Today's Artwork|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/banksy-pays-homage-to-the-twin-towers-2013-10|work=Business Insider|accessdate=21 October 2013}}</ref> with an identical depiction along the [[Brooklyn Heights Promenade]], facing the downtown skyline.<ref>{{cite news|title=Banksy Reveals 9/11 Tribute Piece In New York City|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/10/15/banksy-911-tribute_n_4101204.html|work=[[Huffington Post]]|accessdate=21 October 2013|first=Priscilla|last=Frank|date=15 October 2013}}</ref> The Brooklyn Heights piece was eventually buffed out by the city,<ref>{{cite news|title=City ‘cleans up’ after Banksy art|url=https://nypost.com/2013/10/17/city-cleans-up-after-banksy-art/|work=[[New York Post]]|accessdate=21 October 2013}}</ref> requiring chemicals and a high-powered pressure washer. The removal followed a taunt Banksy had directed toward the city on his website.<ref>{{cite news|last=MacIntosh|first=Jeane|title=How New York City erased Banksy|url=https://nypost.com/2013/10/17/elusive-banksy-unfazed-by-nypd-threats/|work=New York Post|accessdate=21 October 2013}}</ref> Meanwhile, the sister piece in TriBeCa served as a shrine, people placing flowers next to it, as well as a letter asking no one to touch the painting.<ref>{{cite web|last=Boyle|first=Wickham|title=Banksy’s Twin Towers tribute draws crowds to Tribeca alley|url=http://www.downtownexpress.com/2013/10/18/banksys-twin-tower-tribute-draws-crowds-to-tribeca-alley/|archive-url=https://archive.is/20131021075930/http://www.downtownexpress.com/2013/10/18/banksys-twin-tower-tribute-draws-crowds-to-tribeca-alley/|dead-url=yes|archive-date=21 October 2013|work=Downtown Express|accessdate=21 October 2013}}</ref> [[Acrylic glass]] was eventually installed to protect the piece,<ref>{{cite web|last=Tcholakian|first=Danielle|title=Banksy’s Twin Towers protected by plexiglass, loved by little girl|url=http://www.metro.us/boston/news/local/2013/10/17/banksys-twin-towers-protected-by-plexiglass-loved-by-little-girl/|work=Metro US|accessdate=21 October 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131022072453/http://www.metro.us/boston/news/local/2013/10/17/banksys-twin-towers-protected-by-plexiglass-loved-by-little-girl/|archivedate=22 October 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref> before someone painted over it.<ref>{{cite web|last=Carlson|first=Jen|title=Banksy's Twin Towers Pieces Gone, Defaced|url=http://gothamist.com/2013/10/18/banksys_911_tributes_gone_defaced.php|work=Gothamist|accessdate=21 October 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131021040154/http://gothamist.com/2013/10/18/banksys_911_tributes_gone_defaced.php|archivedate=21 October 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Banksy extended his work beyond the canvas and city street with other political statements, including on 16 October, when he crafted a giant [[fiberglass]] sculpture of [[Ronald McDonald]], with a real live Banksy assistant shining its shoes. It was unveiled in [[the Bronx]] but was moved outside of a different [[McDonald's]] restaurant across the city around lunch time for several days. The work criticized the "heavy labor required to sustain the polished image of a mega-corporation", as the narrator of the audio accompaniment put it.<ref>{{cite web|last=Grant |first=Drew |url=http://observer.com/2013/10/banksys-ronald-mcdonald-statue-and-live-shoeshine-boy-take-manhattan/ |title=Banksy Unveils 'Shoeshine Boy' at McDonald's | The New York Observer |publisher=[[The New York Observer]]|date=16 October 2013 |accessdate=17 October 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Jeane MacIntosh, Larry Celona and Bruce Golding |url=https://nypost.com/2013/10/16/banksy-clowns-around-in-new-work/ |title=Banksy zings McDonald’s | New York Post |publisher=New York Post |date=16 October 2013 |accessdate=17 October 2013}}</ref>
On 18 October there was a pair of paintings that Banksy collaborated on with Os Gemeos depicting a single soldier amongst masked citizens and vice versa. "The audio commentary Banksy provided suggests that this piece functions both as situational criticism of the art world as well as a tribute to the Occupy movement. Yet it also recognizes that the installation may be unsuccessful at actually advancing any agenda".<ref>{{Cite book|title = Banksy In New York|last = Mock|first = Ray|publisher = Carnage NYC|year = |isbn = 978-0-9906437-0-8|location = New York|pages = }}</ref>
Banksy's second trip to the [[South Bronx]] was on 21 October and resulted in a piece depicting a child spray-painting the words "Ghetto 4 Life" on a wall, while a butler waited on him with a platter of spray paints. The work immediately drew a crowd from fans, despite angering many residents, who found the message offensive.<ref name=independent_bronx>{{cite news|last=Wyatt|first=Daisy|title=Banksy upsets Bronx residents with 'Ghetto 4 Life' graffiti|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/art/news/banksy-upsets-bronx-residents-with-ghetto-4-life-graffiti-8898535.html|work=[[The Independent]]|accessdate=2 November 2013|location=London|date=23 October 2013}}</ref><ref name=daily_bronx>{{cite news|last=Scarborough|first=Joey|title=Banksy’s latest work annoys Bronx residents|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/new-york/bronx/banksy-ghetto-4-life-work-offends-article-1.1492198|work=New York Daily News|accessdate=2 November 2013}}</ref>
The Sphinx sculpture appeared on a worksite in [[Willets Point, Queens|Willets Point]] on 22 October, entitled ''Everything but the kitchen sphinx'', and was quickly swarmed by eager Banksy fans. The attention caught the workers interest, who were reportedly selling bricks for $100 each, and onlookers watched as it was loaded into a truck and taken away.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://gothamist.com/2013/10/22/who_owns_the_queens_banksy_sculptur.php#photo-1|title=Who "Owns" The Queens Banksy Sculpture?|work=Gothamist|access-date=2018-01-07|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.timesledger.com/stories/2015/22/banksy_2015_05_29_q.html|title=A Queens’ creation by street artist Banksy resurfaces in New York|work=TimesLedger|access-date=2018-01-07|language=en}}</ref> The fate of this piece was heavily chronicled by the HBO documentary ''[[Banksy Does New York]]'' (2014).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.complex.com/style/2014/11/things-we-learned-from-the-banksy-takes-new-york-hbo-documentary/sphinx|title=15 Things We Learned From the "Banksy Does New York" HBO Documentary The Sphinx piece at Willets Point in Queens was lifted by mechanics in the area who were about to lose their business.|website=Complex|language=en|access-date=2018-01-07}}</ref> The piece was taken from its original site, kept in a garage and later appeared in the Art Miami New York modern art fair.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.timesledger.com/stories/2015/22/banksy_2015_05_29_q.html|title=A Queens’ creation by street artist Banksy resurfaces in New York|work=TimesLedger|access-date=2018-01-07|language=en}}</ref>
[[File:"Waiting in Vain" Banksy in Hells Kitchen October 2013.jpg|thumb|left|''Waiting in Vain'', Banksy's 24th installment outside a [[Hustler Club]] in [[Hell's Kitchen, Manhattan|Hell's Kitchen]].]]
The 23rd installment was cancelled due to police activity, according to Banksy's official website, which stirred rumors that he had come under arrest.<ref>{{cite web|last=Yakas|first=Ben|title=Today's New Banksy Was...Cancelled By Police Activity|url=http://gothamist.com/2013/10/23/photos_new_banksy_piece_goes_up_in.php|work=Gothamist|accessdate=3 November 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131026041501/http://gothamist.com/2013/10/23/photos_new_banksy_piece_goes_up_in.php|archivedate=26 October 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref> That same day, an outlined canvas with the caption "Better Out Than In #AnonymousGuestbook" appeared on a building in [[Red Hook, Brooklyn|Red Hook]]. The idea of an open-canvas collaborative piece was presented to Banksy two weeks prior by a community art director. The story then led many to believe the "anonymous guestbook" was outlined by Banksy himself,<ref>{{cite news|last=Goldstein|first=Sasha|title=Banksy gets help from budding Michelangelos with Red Hook Art Project|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/new-york/brooklyn/red-hook-kids-pitch-bansky-article-1.1494689|work=New York Daily News|accessdate=3 November 2013}}</ref> however this was later debunked to have been the work of a group under the name Anonymous Guestbook.<ref>{{cite web|last=Cush|first=Andy|title=SORRY, THE "ANONYMOUS GUESTBOOK" ISN’T BANKSY|url=http://animalnewyork.com/2013/sorry-the-anonymous-guestbook-isnt-banksy/|work=Animal New York|accessdate=3 November 2013}}</ref>
''Waiting in Vain'' was the show's 24th installment. Located outside a [[strip club]] in [[Hell's Kitchen, Manhattan|Hell's Kitchen]], it illustrated a man in a [[tuxedo]] holding flowers, presumably jilted by his date.<ref>{{cite web|last=Bucktin|first=Christopher|title=Banksy is back! Notorious graffiti artist eludes chasing police again to create new image in New York|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/world-news/banksy-created-new-work-larry-2561821#.UuBpamQo62w|work=Mirror News|accessdate=23 January 2014}}</ref> After some of the club's entertainers posed in front of the piece, the owner had it carefully cut from the shutter gate before vandals could deface it. It is planned to go on permanent display inside the club.<ref>{{cite web|last=Heins|first=Scott|title=Photos, Video: The Night They Drove Old Banksy Down|url=http://gothamist.com/2013/10/25/banksy_hustler_club_stripper_video.php|work=Gothamist|accessdate=23 January 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140210112052/http://gothamist.com/2013/10/25/banksy_hustler_club_stripper_video.php|archivedate=10 February 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
The 25th piece came suitably [[Halloween]]-themed. Located on the [[Bowery]], it exhibited a [[Grim Reaper]] riding a [[bumper car]] in circles to an elaborate light show, [[fog machine]] and [[Blue Öyster Cult]]'s "[[(Don't Fear) The Reaper]]."<ref name=daily_reaper>{{cite news|last=Stebner|first=Beth|title=Banksy on the Bowery: Artist debuts spooky Grim Reaper that thrills New Yorkers|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/new-york/banksy-bowery-artist-debuts-spooky-grim-reaper-article-1.1497493|work=New York Daily News|accessdate=3 November 2013}}</ref> The accompanying audio guide offered a self-mocking interpretation, with Banksy stating that often "the role of art is to remind us of our mortality," implying that with this mounted art show that goes on "for so long we wish we were dead already."<ref>{{cite web|last=Dodero |first=Camille |title=Banksy's Newest NYC Installation: The Grim Reaper in a Bumper Car |url=http://gawker.com/banksys-newest-nyc-installation-the-grim-reaper-in-a-1452430639 |work=[[Gawker]] |accessdate=3 November 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131030090617/http://gawker.com/banksys-newest-nyc-installation-the-grim-reaper-in-a-1452430639 |archivedate=30 October 2013 |df=dmy }}</ref> The site of the exhibit was once that of an antique shop, some remains of which were placed in a coffin that occupied the lot for months. This prompted other interpretations of the installation's message, paying homage to the "ghosts of Bowry," as the antique store owner suggested.<ref name=daily_reaper />
The 27 October piece was a message on a wall in Greenpoint that read "This site contains blocked messages." It made reference to an unpublished column Banksy had submitted to ''[[The New York Times]]''. The controversial essay criticized the city's decision in approving the [[One World Trade Center]], which he described as "vanilla" and looking like "something they would build in Canada."<ref name=cnn_wtc>{{cite news|last=Draznin|first=Haley|title=Banksy calls One World Trade Center a "betrayal"|url=http://www.cnn.com/2013/10/28/us/banksy-world-trade-center-editorial/index.html|work=CNN|accessdate=3 November 2013|date=28 October 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Moya-Smith|first=Simon|title=British street artist Banksy trashes design of One World Trade Center|url=http://usnews.nbcnews.com/_news/2013/10/27/21194968-british-street-artist-banksy-trashes-design-of-one-world-trade-center|work=[[NBC News]]|accessdate=3 November 2013}}</ref> In what became his second reference to the [[September 11 attacks]], Banksy argued the building was a betrayal to everyone who lost their lives that day, and that its blandness is a sign the terrorist won.<ref>{{cite web|last=Simpson|first=Connor|title=Banksy Really Hates the New World Trade Center Building|url=http://www.theatlanticwire.com/national/2013/10/banksy-really-hates-new-world-trade-center-building/70980/|work=[[The Atlantic Wire]]|accessdate=3 November 2013}}</ref>
The final piece of the month-long series was a group of balloons that together read "BANKSY!", tied to the wall of a building alongside the [[Long Island Expressway]] in Queens. Banksy included the message "Save [[5 Pointz|5pointz]]" in the caption for the piece on his website, referring to 5 Pointz, a nearby outdoor art exhibit considered to be a focal point of such culture<ref>{{cite news|last=Boyette|first=Chris|title=Banksy bids farewell to New York with balloons|url=http://www.cnn.com/2013/10/31/us/new-york-banksy-residency-ends/|work=CNN|accessdate=3 November 2013|date=1 November 2013}}</ref> that had recently been approved by the [[New York City Department of City Planning]] to be [[5 Pointz#Demolition plans|demolished]] to make way for condominiums.<ref>{{cite web|title=5Pointz Not Alone: City Planning Commission Also Approves Huge Hallets Point Project|url=http://queens.brownstoner.com/2013/08/the-city-planning-commission-votes-for-big-changes-in-queens-today/|work=brownstoner.com|accessdate=3 November 2013}}</ref> {{clear}}
==Defacement== {{Main|Works by Banksy damaged or destroyed}} Most of the works that make up the ''Better Out Than In'' series were [[Defacement (vandalism)|defaced]], some just hours after the piece was unveiled.<ref name=nytimes_welcome>{{cite news|title=Banksy’s New York Welcome|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/10/16/opinion/banksys-new-york-welcome.html|work=New York Times|accessdate=21 October 2013|date=15 October 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Janeczko|first=Jane|title=Banksy Piece In Queens Defaced By Other Graffiti Artists|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/10/15/banksy-destroyed_n_4101145.html|work=Huffington Post|accessdate=21 October 2013|date=15 October 2013}}</ref> At least one defacement was identified as done by a competing artist, OMAR NYC, who spray-painted over Banksy's red mylar balloon piece in Red Hook.<ref>{{cite news|last=Janeczko|first=Jane|title=Banksy Hater, OMAR NYC, Defaces Art In Red Hook|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/10/08/banksy-hater-defaces_n_4065250.html|work=Huffington Post|accessdate=21 October 2013|date=8 October 2013}}</ref> OMAR NYC also defaced some of Banksy's work in May 2010.<ref>{{cite web|last=Turco|first=Bucky|title=BANKSY THOROUGHLY RAGGED|url=http://animalnewyork.com/2010/banksy-thoroughly-ragged/|work=Animal New York|accessdate=21 October 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Dobkin|first=Jake|title=Banksy Gets Dissed|url=http://gothamist.com/2010/05/18/banksy_gets_dissed.php?#photo-1|work=Gothamist|accessdate=21 October 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131010072201/http://gothamist.com/2010/05/18/banksy_gets_dissed.php#photo-1|archivedate=10 October 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
As a result of the continued defacement, fans rushed to the sites of the installments as soon as they are announced.<ref name=nytimes_race /> A group of men took advantage of this and threatened to deface a stencil painting of a beaver in [[East New York]], charging money for people to take photographs.<ref>{{cite web |last=Jefferson |first=Cord |title=These Men Are Now Charging People to Look at Banksy's Latest Stencil |url=http://gawker.com/these-men-are-now-charging-people-to-look-at-banksys-l-1443562694 |work=[[Gawker]] |accessdate=21 October 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131019141644/http://gawker.com/these-men-are-now-charging-people-to-look-at-banksys-l-1443562694 |archivedate=19 October 2013 |df=dmy }}</ref><ref name=nytimes_monthlong>{{cite news|last=Buckley|first=Cara|title=Monthlong Chase Around New York City for Banksy’s Street Art|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/10/29/nyregion/monthlong-chase-around-new-york-city-for-banksys-street-art.html|accessdate=3 November 2013|newspaper=New York Times|date=28 October 2013}}</ref> Some took matters into their own hands by guarding the works, others restoring them once defaced.<ref>{{cite news|last=Caulfield|first=Philip|title=Banksy fans restore Williamsburg ‘geishas’ after tussle with tagger|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/new-york/banksy-fans-restore-williamsburg-geishas-tussle-tagger-article-1.1488985|work=New York Daily News|accessdate=21 October 2013}}</ref> In part because of the defacement, but also because of the great value of the artworks, property owners have also gone to extreme measures to protect the art. Some hired security guards, others covered the art with [[acrylic glass]], and yet others installed metal roll-down gates.<ref name=nytimes_monthlong /><ref name=huffguard>{{cite news|title=Banksy Work Requires Guards In NYC|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/10/20/banksy-work-guards_n_4131620.html|work=[[Associated Press]]|publisher=Huffington Post|accessdate=20 October 2013|date=20 October 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=NYC building owner installs gate, hires guards to save work by elusive graffiti artist Banksy|url=http://www.startribune.com/entertainment/228465671.html|work=[[Associated Press]]|publisher=[[Star Tribune]]|accessdate=21 October 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131021065226/http://www.startribune.com/entertainment/228465671.html|archivedate=21 October 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==Response==
The month-long show was widely publicized and covered by the media. Mayor [[Michael Bloomberg]], while supporting the arts, criticized Banksy's work, calling him a vandal,<ref>{{cite web|last=Zeveloff|first=Julie|title=Banksy Taunts Cops After Mayor Bloomberg Calls Him A Vandal|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/banksy-taunts-cops-after-bloomberg-calls-him-a-vandal-2013-10|work=[[Business Insider]]|accessdate=20 October 2013}}</ref> contending that defacing property was not his definition of art.<ref name=huffington_bloomberg>{{cite news|last=Gutterman|first=Amanda|title=Calling for a Bloomberg-Banksy Ceasfire|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/amanda-gutterman/banksy-new-york_b_4125535.html|work=Huffington Post|accessdate=3 November 2013|date=21 October 2013}}</ref>
On 17 October the ''[[New York Post]]'' wrote under the front-page headline "Get Banksy!" that police were pursuing Banksy, but noted the hunt is difficult because he has never been positively identified in public.<ref name=atlanticwire>{{cite web|last=Schonfeld|first=Zach|title=The NYPD Is Finding it 'Kind of Hard' to Hunt Down Banksy|url=http://www.theatlanticwire.com/entertainment/2013/10/hunting-down-banksy-is-kind-of-hard-for-nypd/70650/|work=The Atlantic Wire|accessdate=21 October 2013}}</ref> In response Banksy posted an image of the front page on his website with the caption "I don't read what i believe in the papers."<ref>{{cite web|title=Banksy riles Big Apple|url=http://www.brisbanetimes.com.au/entertainment/art-and-design/banksy-riles-big-apple-20131019-2vtvl.html|work=[[Brisbane Times]]|accessdate=21 October 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Local Artists Say Banksy "Defacing" Claims Overblown|url=http://www.ny1.com/content/lifestyles/arts/190737/local-artists-say-banksy--defacing--claims-overblown|work=[[NY1]]|accessdate=21 October 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131021064952/http://www.ny1.com/content/lifestyles/arts/190737/local-artists-say-banksy--defacing--claims-overblown|archivedate=21 October 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The [[NYPD]] later denied they were actively looking for Banksy as no property owners had filed any formal complaints.<ref>{{cite news|last=Tracy|first=Thomas|title=Banksy debuts latest piece in Brooklyn as NYPD denies cops are hunting for the elusive graffiti artist|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/crime/nypd-searching-banksy-source-article-1.1488808|work=New York Daily News|accessdate=20 October 2013}}</ref>
===Controversy=== [[File:"Ghetto 4 Life" Banksy in South Bronx October 2013.jpg|thumb|right|Banksy's 21 October piece in the [[South Bronx]] angered many residents and graffiti artists.]] [[The Bronx|Bronx]] [[Borough President]] [[Rubén Díaz, Jr.]] called Banksy a "modern-day Picasso" and praised him for choosing to unveil his 16 October Ronald McDonald replica in the South Bronx.<ref>{{cite web|last=Carlson|first=Jen|title=Photos, Video: Banksy's New Piece Is A Traveling Ronald McDonald Statue|url=http://gothamist.com/2013/10/16/photos_ronald_mcdonald.php|work=Gothamist|accessdate=3 November 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131019220758/http://gothamist.com/2013/10/16/photos_ronald_mcdonald.php|archivedate=19 October 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name=daily_bronx2>{{cite news|last=Scarborough|first=Joey|title=Borough President Ruben Diaz disses Banksy one day after ‘Ghetto 4 Life’ slur|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/new-york/bronx/bronx-borough-president-reviles-banksy-article-1.1493215|work=New York Daily News|accessdate=3 November 2013}}</ref> This came before Banksy's 21 October piece, which brought discontent to the President and other residents. The piece featured a child spray-painting the words "Ghetto 4 Life" on a wall. Díaz stated it reinforced "outdated negative stereotypes," and defended that Banksy should become aware that graffiti art and culture originated in the Bronx.<ref name=independent_bronx /><ref name=daily_bronx2 /> The owner of the graffitied wall and his partner, however, praised the work and its message, calling it "beautiful" and owning its preservation to the artist's fame.<ref name=daily_bronx /><ref name=daily_bronx2 />
Banksy's [[op-ed]] article about One World Trade Center, posted on his website on 27 October, came as an insult to many across the city. Former [[FDNY]] Deputy Chief Jim Riches wrote that it was a "disgrace to New York City and all the families who lost loved ones on 9/11."<ref name=cnn_wtc /> [[Sally Regenhard]], a leading voice for families of [[Casualties of the September 11 attacks|11 September victims]], expressed concerns about Banksy's 15 October depiction of the Twin Towers in TriBeCa, saying the piece was "horrific" and that the placed flower looked more like an explosion.<ref>{{cite news|last=Blau|first=Reuven|title=Banksy criticizes 1 World Trade Center as ‘Canadian,’ ‘vanilla’|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/new-york/banksy-disses-1-wtc-canadian-vanilla-article-1.1498564|work=New York Daily News|accessdate=3 November 2013}}</ref> A [[Century 21 (department store)|Century 21]] department store near [[World Trade Center site|Ground Zero]] had planned to show Banksy's work on 29 October, but cancelled due to the controversy.<ref name=cnn_wtc />
===Critical reception=== Banksy's ''Better Out Than In'' series has received mixed reviews.<ref name=npr_review>{{cite web|last=Rose|first=Joel|title=Art Or Act? New Yorkers Give Banksy Residency Mixed Reviews|url=https://www.npr.org/2013/10/31/242028452/art-or-act-banksys-reviews-are-mixed|work=[[NPR]]|accessdate=4 November 2013}}</ref> Many fans raved over his work, flocking to each site everyday of the show.<ref>{{cite news|last=Buckley|first=Cara|title=Monthlong Chase Around New York City for Banksy’s Street Art|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/10/29/nyregion/monthlong-chase-around-new-york-city-for-banksys-street-art.html|work=New York Times|accessdate=4 November 2013|date=28 October 2013}}</ref>
''[[New York City|New York]]'' magazine art critic [[Jerry Saltz]] wrote Banksy's well-executed work stood out from other graffiti, but that the meaning behind the pieces aren't as deep as fans like to believe.<ref name=npr_review /> "No other graffiti artist has a [[Public relations|PR]] machine remotely like Banksy's," he writes, arguing Banksy is more of a "promo man" than an artist.<ref name=saltz_ranking>{{cite web|last=Saltz|first=Jerry|title=Jerry Saltz Ranks Banksy’s New York City (So-Called) Artistic Works|url=http://www.vulture.com/2013/10/saltz-ranking-banksys-nyc-pieces.html|work=[[Vulture (blog)|Vulture]]|publisher=[[New York Magazine]]|accessdate=4 November 2013}}</ref>
Will Ellsworth-Jones, author of ''Banksy: The Man Behind the Wall'' writes that ''Better Out Than In'' shows Banksy's range of mediums has grown to incorporate multi-media and performance-based works. He pointed out the "wonderful commentary on money and art" displayed with hiring an anonymous salesman to sell Banksy paintings in Central Park for $60.<ref name=npr_review />
==See also== {{Portal|Graffiti|New York City}} * [[Graffiti in New York City]] * [[List of damaged or destroyed works by Banksy]]
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== {{Commons category|Better Out Than In}}

{| class="infobox" style="text-align:left; width:230px; font-size:85%;" |- |+ '''BiennaleOnline''' |- | colspan="2" align="center" | [[File:BiennaleOnline logo.png|110px]] |- ! style="width:115px;" | Genre | style="width:115px;" | Contemporary Art |- ! style="width:115px;" | Frequency | style="width:115px;" | Every 2 years |- ! style="width:115px;" | Launched | style="width:115px;" | April 26, 2013 |- | colspan="2" |
'''Overview'''
|- ! style="width:115px;" | Founded | style="width:115px;" | {{start date|2012}} |- ! style="width:115px;" | Founders | style="width:115px;" | {{nowrap|David Dehaeck}}
{{nowrap|Nathalie Haveman}} |- ! style="width:115px;" | Organizers | style="width:115px;" | ART + |- | colspan="2" |
'''Website'''
|- | colspan="2" style="text-align:center;" | {{URL|www.biennaleonline.org}} |- |} '''BiennaleOnline''' is a biennial [[Art exhibition|exhibition]] of [[contemporary art]]. This exhibition's platform is the first of its kind to be held online.{{cite web | url=http://www.flashartonline.com/interno.php?pagina=news_det&id=1598&det=ok&title=An-online-biennale? | title=An online biennale? | publisher=''Flash Art Online'' | date=January 24, 2013 | accessdate=February 11, 2013 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140314000204/http://www.flashartonline.com/interno.php?pagina=news_det&id=1598&det=ok&title=An-online-biennale%3F# | archive-date=2014-03-14 | dead-url=yes | df= }} The exhibition aims to focus on the most promising emerging visual artists worldwide, presenting works in [[New Media]], [[Installation art|Installation]], Traditional Media, [[Photography]] and [[Performance]]. These artists will come from [[Europe]], [[North America]], [[South America]], [[Asia]], and the [[Middle East]], and have been selected by 29 leading international curators.{{cite web | url=http://www.biennialfoundation.org/2013/01/first-online-biennial-exhibition-of-conteporary-art-launching-april-26-2013-biennaleonlines-inaugural-exhibition-is-titled-reflection-imagination/ | title=First online biennial exhibition of contemporary art. Launching April 26, 2013, BiennaleOnline's inaugural exhibition is titled "Reflection & Imagination". | publisher=''Biennial Foundation'' | date=January 17, 2013 | accessdate=February 10, 2013}}{{cite web | url=http://www.knack.be/belga-algemeen/jan-hoet-leidt-eerste-online-kunstbiennale-ter-wereld/article-4000238417843.htm | title=Jan Hoet leidt eerste online kunstbiënnale ter wereld | publisher=''[[Knack (magazine)|Knack]]'' | work=[[Belga (news agency)|Belga]] | accessdate=February 11, 2013 | author=January 24, 2013 | language= Dutch}}{{cite web | url=http://www.demorgen.be/dm/nl/1006/Kunst-Literatuur/article/detail/1568172/2013/01/24/Jan-Hoet-leidt-eerste-online-kunstbiennale-ter-wereld.dhtmll/ | title=Jan Hoet leidt eerste online kunstbiënnale ter wereld | publisher=''[[De Morgen]]'' | date=January 24, 2013 | accessdate=February 11, 2013 | language= Dutch}} The inaugural exhibition launched on April 26, 2013 and is called "''Reflection & Imagination''" with [[Jan Hoet]] serving as the [[art director|artistic director]].{{cite web | url=http://www.artinfo.com/news/story/861877/tracey-emins-broadway-debut-musee-dorsay-puts-out-the-poor-and | title=Tracey Emin's Broadway Debut, Musée d'Orsay Puts Out the Poor, and More | publisher=''[[Louise Blouin Media|Blouin ArtInfo]]'' | date=January 30, 2013 | accessdate=February 11, 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.kulturize.com/le-biennali-continuano-moltiplicarsi-diventano-anche-virtuali-da-aprile-la-prima-biennaleonline/ |title=Le biennali continuano a moltiplicarsi. E diventano anche virtuali: da aprile la prima BiennaleOnline |publisher=''Kulturize'' |date=February 4, 2013 |accessdate=February 11, 2013 |author=Saviour Puzella |language=Italian |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130528195229/http://www.kulturize.com/le-biennali-continuano-moltiplicarsi-diventano-anche-virtuali-da-aprile-la-prima-biennaleonline/ |archivedate=May 28, 2013 |df= }} ==Overview== BiennaleOnline was founded by David Dehaeck and Nathalie Haveman in 2012. The exhibition was set to be launched on September 2012, however it was moved to April 2013.{{cite web | url=http://www.artdaily.org/index.asp?int_sec=11&int_new=54541#.URkWJKJeGQk | title=New mobile platform for smart investments in emerging Contemporary art | publisher=''Art Daily'' | accessdate=February 12, 2013}} The exhibition is organized by ARTPLUS, a mobile exhibition platform for art lovers and collectors of contemporary art.{{cite web | url=http://www.artinamericamagazine.com/news-opinion/news/2013-01-29/online-biennial/ | title=Does the Art World Need an Online Biennial? | publisher=''[[Art in America]]'' | date=January 29, 2013 | accessdate=February 11, 2013 | author=Brian Boucher}}{{cite web | url=http://www.deredactie.be/cm/vrtnieuws.francais/magazine/130125_JanHoetBiennaleOnline/ | title=Jan Hoet dirige la première biennale d’art en ligne | publisher=''Deredactie'' | date=January 15, 2013 | accessdate=February 11, 2013 | language= French}} {{dead link|date=March 2014}} The first BiennaleOnline is directed by [[Jan Hoet]]. Hoet previously served as the artistic director of [[Documenta IX]] and the museum [[MARTa Herford]], [[Germany]], and was a founder of [[SMAK]] in Ghent, Belgium. 25 artists, which are carefully chosen by Hoet, will be represented in the center section of the exhibition called "''Reflection & Imagination''".{{cite web | url=http://www.excelsior.com.mx/2013/02/06/882901/ | title=Encuentro de creación en la web, crean una bienal en línea | publisher=''[[Excélsior]]'' | date=February 6, 2013 | accessdate=February 11, 2013 | author=Sonia Ávila | language= Spanish}} Jan Hoet died in a hospital in Ghent on February 27, 2014. BiennaleOnline is the first of its kind, curated, exclusively online biennial exhibition of contemporary art. 29 Leading international curators select the 183 most promising artists at a critical moment, when they are poised to become established artists. BiennaleOnline aimes to offer an exhibition which breaks away from the conventional notion of Art as an elite pastime, confined to faraway galleries and those with the leisure and funds to enjoy it. BiennaleOnline started with a "Pay What You want" payment wall. The founders very soon noticed that it was blocking visitors from entering the exhibition. In the best interest of the artists it was decided in May 2012 to remove the payment wall to ensure maximum exposure of their works. Soon after the removal of the payment wall the number of visitors surged to 400.000 within 1 year after opening. ==Exhibitions== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center; font-size:100%; line-height:16px;" width="80%" |- ! colspan="2" | Exhibition ! bgcolor=#dddddd | Launched ! bgcolor=#dddddd | Artistic Director ! bgcolor=#dddddd | Central Exhibition ! bgcolor=#dddddd | Artists ! bgcolor=#dddddd | Curators ! bgcolor=#dddddd | Visitors |- ! I ! Ortiz|Daniela Ortiz]] (Spain) *Sener Özmen (Turkey) *Amilkar Packer (Brazil) *[[Anna Parkina]] (Russian Federation) *Slawomir Pawszak (Poland) *Kiko Perez (Spain) *Dulce Pinzón (Mexico) {{col-break}} *Falke Pisano (Netherlands) *Frédéric Platéus (Belgium) *Sharon Poliakine (Israel) *Paloma Polo (Spain) *[[:pl:Agnieszka Polska|Agnieszka Polska]] (Poland) *[[Nicolas Provost]] (Belgium) *Florian [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nR8d3A8r7J8 Jan Hoet BiennaleOnline 2013] ==The second BiennaleOnline== The second BiennaleOnline will launch in 2017 . The BiennaleOnline attracted more than 400.000 visitors since its launch in April 2012. The success the BiennaleOnline led to the decision to present the exhibition on its native platform separate from ART+. In 2014 ART+ modified its business model to focus solely on facilitating secure ownership and trade of media art online. {{good article}} {{Infobox manuscript | name = Birds' Head Haggadah | location = [[Israel Museum]] | image = File:Scribe- Menahem - The Birds' Head Haggadah - Google Art Project.jpg | width = 300px | caption = Manuscript pages showing text of [[Haggadah]] with illustrations of bird-headed Jews baking [[matzo]] for [[Passover]] | Type = [[Illuminated manuscript]] | Date = c. 1300 | Place of origin = Southern Germany | Language(s) = [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]] | Scribe(s) = Menahem | Material = Dark brown ink and [[tempera]] on parchment | Size = {{convert|27|x|18.2|cm}}; 50 pages (originally) | Format = | Condition = | Script = Block calligraphy | Contents = [[Haggadah]] for [[Passover]], with accompanying illustrations | Illumination(s) = | Additions = | Exemplar(s) = | Previously kept = Owned by [[Ludwig Marum]] until 1933 | Discovered = Purchased by Israel Museum in 1946 | Accession = | Other = }} The '''Birds' Head Haggadah''' (c. 1300) is the oldest surviving [[Illuminated manuscript|illuminated]] [[Ashkenazi Jews|Ashkenazi]] [[Passover]] [[Haggadah]].{{sfn|Hourihane|2012|p=350}}{{sfn|Estrin|2016}} The manuscript, produced in the [[Upper Rhine]] region of Southern Germany in the early 14th century, contains the full Hebrew text of the Haggadah, a ritual text recounting the story of Passover – the liberation of the [[Israelites]] from slavery in [[ancient Egypt]] – which is recited by participants at a [[Passover Seder]]. The text is executed in block calligraphy and accompanied by colorful illustrations of Jews performing the Seder practices and reenacting Jewish historical events. The Birds' Head Haggadah is so called because all Jewish men, women, and children depicted in the manuscript have human bodies with the faces and beaks of [[bird]]s. Non-Jewish and non-human faces (such as those of angels, the sun, and the moon) are blank or blurred. Numerous theories have been advanced to explain the unusual [[iconography]], usually tied to [[Aniconism in Judaism|Jewish aniconism]]. The Haggadah is in the possession of the [[Israel Museum]] in [[Jerusalem]], where it is on permanent exhibition. ==Description== A [[Haggadah]] is a ritual Jewish text containing prayers, hymns, [[Midrash]]ic statements, and commentary on the story of [[Passover]] – the liberation of the [[Israelites]] from slavery in [[ancient Egypt]]. This text is recited by participants at a [[Passover Seder]].{{cite web |url=http://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/the-passover-haggadah|title=Passover: The Haggadah|publisher=[[Jewish Virtual Library]]|year=2017|accessdate=12 September 2017}}{{sfn|Italie|2011}} Illuminated manuscripts of the Haggadah began appearing in the 13th century, and printed Haggadahs began to be published in the 15th century.{{sfn|Cohen|2017}} The Birds' Head Haggadah is an [[illuminated manuscript]] dated to the beginning of the 14th century.{{sfn|Hourihane|2012|p=350}} The style and coloring of the figures reflects that of other illuminated manuscripts from the Upper Rhine region of Southern Germany in that era,{{sfn|Hourihane|2012|p=350}} perhaps from the vicinity of [[Würzburg]],{{Cite journal|last=Schubert|first=Ursula|date=1988|title=Die Vogelkopf-Haggada. Ein künstlerisches Zeugnis jüdischen Selbstbewusstseins am Ende des 13. Jahrhunderts.|url=|journal=Anzeiger des germanischen Nationalmuseums|location=Nürnberg|volume=|pages=35–37|via=}} and the architectural backgrounds are sufficiently detailed to date and locate the manuscript.{{sfn|Schapiro|1980|p=382}} The Birds' Head Haggadah is believed to be the first illustrated Haggadah produced in its own binding, distinct from the [[siddur|Jewish prayer book]]. The manuscript measures {{convert|27|cm}} long by {{convert|18.2|cm}} wide. It is believed to have originally contained about 50 pages, gathered into five bindings of eight pages each and one binding of 10 pages.{{sfn|Raff|2005}} In its current condition, it contains 47 pages.{{sfn|Epstein|2015|p=97}} ===Text=== The text was copied by a scribe named Menahem; the letters of his Hebrew name, מנחם, are graphically accentuated in the similarly-spelled Hebrew word מֻנָּחִים (''Munahim'') in the Haggadah text, [[Hebrew abbreviations#Text|revealing his signature]].{{sfn|Raff|2005}}{{efn|The passage in which the Hebrew word ''Munahim'' ("are placed") appears references the Jew's obligation to recite the Haggadah when the [[matzo]] and [[maror]] are placed before him.{{sfn|Touger|2017}}}} The scribe Menahem is also credited with copying the [[Leipzig]] [[Machzor]] ([[High Holy Days]] prayerbook) around the same time; he encoded his name in that illuminated manuscript in a "decorated text panel".{{sfn|Fishof|1994|p=58}}{{sfn|McBee|2009}} Each page of the Birds' Head Haggadah contains 12 rows of text, copied in block calligraphy.{{sfn|Raff|2005}} The calligraphy and illustrations were executed in dark brown ink and [[tempera]] on parchment.{{sfn|Hourihane|2012|p=350}} The extant manuscript shows smaller, densely packed script written in the margins of some pages, detailing instructions for conducting the Seder and fulfilling the [[Halakha|laws]] pertaining to Passover.{{sfn|Raff|2005}} "Captions" have also been appended to certain illustrations.{{sfn|Epstein|2011|p=47}} According to Epstein, these glosses and captions were added by unknown owners of the Haggadah over the centuries.{{sfn|Epstein|2011|p=47}} ===Illustrations=== [[File:3 figures - The Birds' Head Haggadah - Google Art Project (cropped).jpg|225px|right|thumb|(L. to r.) A Jewish man, woman, and child shape and prick holes in handmade [[matzo]]s in preparation for baking]] [[File:Red figure Scribe- Menahem - The Birds' Head Haggadah - Google Art Project (cropped).jpg|225px|right|thumb|Detail of a bird-headed Jewish man placing matzo in an oven]] The manuscript contains two full-page [[Miniature (illuminated manuscript)|miniatures]]. The first, placed at the beginning, depicts a husband and wife seated at their Seder table.{{sfn|Hourihane|2012|p=350}}{{sfn|Raff|2005}} The second, appearing at the end of the Haggadah, depicts a vision of a rebuilt Jerusalem in the messianic era.{{sfn|Hourihane|2012|p=350}} In addition to the full-page miniatures, 33 pages in the manuscript have illustrations in the margins.{{sfn|Epstein|2015|p=97}} These illustrations, which closely follow the text,{{sfn|Roth|1969}} depict Jewish men and women performing Passover and Seder practices, and also reenacting events in Jewish history.{{sfn|Raff|2005}}{{sfn|Epstein|2015|p=97}}{{sfn|Kuruvilla|2016}} The Passover and Seder-themed reenactments include the roasting of the [[Passover sacrifice|Paschal lamb]]; the baking of [[matzo]]s; grinding the [[maror|bitter herbs]]; eating the bitter herbs with [[charoset]]; leaning on one's left side at the Seder; [[Passover Seder#Yachatz (breaking of the middle matzah)|breaking the middle matzo]], and so on.{{sfn|Blank|2011|pp=27, 28–31, 33, 35–36}} Historical depictions include the [[Binding of Isaac]]; the Jewish people hurriedly leaving Egypt with their matzos, which did not have time to rise; Pharaoh and his army pursuing the Jewish nation to the [[Crossing the Red Sea#Biblical narrative|Red Sea]]; [[Moses]] receiving the two [[Tablets of Stone]] from heaven and giving over the [[Pentateuch]] to the Jewish people; and the Jews receiving [[manna]] from heaven during their wanderings in the desert.{{sfn|Epstein|2015|p=99}}{{sfn|Barash|Assmann|Baumgarten|2001|p=151}}{{sfn|Marcus|2015|p=86}}{{sfn|Blank|2011|p=33}}{{sfn|Laderman|2014|pp=368–369}}{{citekill|date=September 2017}} The Jewish characters are dressed in medieval German-Jewish clothing, and the pointed "[[Jewish hat]]" mandated by the Church beginning in the 13th century is seen on Jewish leaders and teachers, including [[Moses]].{{sfn|Raff|2005}}{{sfn|Roth|1969}}{{sfn|Fishof|1994|p=58}}{{sfn|Gindi|1998|p=34}} Yet while the Jewish characters all have human bodies, and some also have human hair and beards, and wear helmets or women's [[Snood (headgear)|snoods]], their faces are those of "sharp-beaked and sharp-eyed birds".{{sfn|Fishof|1994|p=58}}{{sfn|Epstein|2015|pp=97, 99}}{{sfn|Zemel|2016|p=92}} A large beak occupies the place where the nose and mouth should be.{{sfn|Roth|1969}} [[Marc Michael Epstein|Epstein]] notes that the birds' heads are not uniform, but individualized according to the "age, sex, and status" of the character.{{sfn|Epstein|2015|p=100}} Some characters have pigs' ears as well.{{sfn|Hourihane|2012|p=350}} The faces of non-Jewish characters, in contrast – such as Pharaoh and the ancient Egyptians – and non-human characters such as angels, the sun, and the moon, are blank or blurred.{{sfn|Epstein|2015|p=100}} An unknown artist subsequently added facial features to the Egyptian soldiers, but these additions either faded or were rubbed out.{{sfn|Roth|1969}}{{sfn|Epstein|2015|p=99}} [[File:BH Exodus.jpg|600px|center|thumb|Detail of the [[The Exodus|Exodus from Egypt]]: bird-headed Jews bake [[matzo]]s for the journey and leave Egypt with their possessions (left-hand page); a blank-faced Pharaoh and Egyptian soldiers pursue the Jewish nation (right-hand page)]] {{clear}} ==Interpretations== {{Quote box |width=225px |align=right |quoted= |bgcolor= |salign=right |quote = Within the rather modest field of Jewish visual culture it is, in its own unassuming way, as mysterious as the Pyramids of Giza, the monoliths of Easter Island, or Mona Lisa's smile. |source=–Professor [[Marc Michael Epstein]] on the
Birds' Head Haggadah{{sfn|Kuruvilla|2016}} }} Numerous theories have been advanced to explain the choice of facial features in the Haggadah's illustrations. A prevalent theory for the use of bird rather than human faces is the illustrator's attempt to circumvent the Second Commandment prohibition against [[Thou shalt not make unto thee any graven image|making a graven image]], in the tradition of [[Aniconism in Judaism|Jewish aniconism]].{{sfn|Schapiro|1980|p=384}}{{sfn|Estrin|2016}}{{sfn|Gindi|1998|p=34}} Other Ashkenazi Hebrew illuminated manuscripts from the 13th and 14th centuries depict humans with animal heads in keeping with this prohibition.{{sfn|Fishof|1994|p=58}} Notably, the Leipzig Machzor, copied by the same scribe who copied the Birds' Head Haggadah, features human-looking faces with noses resembling curved beaks.{{sfn|McBee|2009}} Epstein theorizes that the choice of birds' heads for the Jewish figures in the Birds' Head Haggadah hints at the spiritual and national characteristics of the Jewish people. He argues that the beaked visages in the manuscript are not birds' heads at all, but the heads of [[griffin]]s. The legendary griffin – the body of which resembles both a lion and an eagle – reflects the prevalent use of "lion-eagle-human hybrids" in Jewish iconography.{{sfn|Epstein|2015|p=101}} Moreover, the lion-eagle-human hybrid incorporates three of the [[Living creatures (Bible)|four creatures]] represented in [[Ezekiel]]'s [[Merkabah mysticism|vision of the divine chariot]] ({{bibleref|Ezekiel|1|RSV}}), suggesting a connection between the Jewish people and God.{{sfn|Epstein|2011|p=57}} [[Lion of Judah|The lion]] may also allude to the symbol of the tribe of [[Tribe of Judah|Judah]] while [[Reichsadler|the eagle]] evokes the symbol of the German emperor, suggesting the Jews' identification as both subjects of the realm and as Jews.{{sfn|Epstein|2011|p=57}} Epstein further theorizes that the blank faces assigned to non-Jewish and non-human figures sends a message to Jewish readers of the Haggadah that these entities have no intrinsic power, but are subject to God's will.{{sfn|Epstein|2015|p=104}} Art historian [[Meyer Schapiro]], who wrote an introduction to the first [[facsimile]] edition of the Haggadah published by M. Spitzer in 1965,{{sfn|Roth|1969}} maintains that the birds' heads are those of eagles, noting a very similar head on "an unmistakable eagle" in the contemporary Christian [[Codex Manesse]]. The [[Reichsadler|Imperial Eagle]] was the heraldic symbol of the [[Holy Roman Emperor]], under whose protection Jews in Germany lived, which the depiction as eagles may symbolize. In addition, a number of biblical passages can be taken as identifying the Jews with eagles, including {{bibleref|Exodus|19:4|RSV}}, especially relevant to the Passover, and {{bibleref|Deuteronomy|32:11–12|RSV}}{{sfn|Schapiro|1980|p=384}} Carol Zemel postulates that the birds' heads affixed to Jewish men and women going about their Passover preparations are a tongue-in-cheek allusion to the [[Theriocephaly|animal-head]] gods worshipped by the ancient Egyptians. This connection elevates the spiritual importance of the Jews' work.{{sfn|Zemel|2016|p=92}} Ruth Malinkoff, in her 1999 book ''Antisemitic Hate Signs in Hebrew: Illuminated Manuscripts from Medieval Germany'', asserts that the appendage of pigs' ears to some Jewish characters clues the reader to the fact that these are [[Antisemitism|antisemitic]] [[caricature]]s instigated by Christian artists. Jewish artists, who were more familiar with the Hebrew text, did the design and copying, and the manuscript was commissioned by Jews as well, but Christian antisemitism heavily influenced the illustrations. This expressed itself in the "[[Jewish nose|stereotypical long noses]]" and "large eyes", the pigs' ears, and the conical hat worn by many Jewish figures. The fact that the birds' heads themselves are those of [[Bird of prey|birds of prey]] – which are [[Tumah and taharah|ritually impure]] according to [[Halakha|Jewish law]] – also point to the antisemitic undertones of the manuscript, according to Malinkoff.{{sfn|Raff|2005}} However, Meyer Schapiro believes the artists were Jewish,{{sfn|Schapiro|1980|p=382, elsewhere he talks of a single artist}} trained in the contemporary Gothic idiom, and confident in their style, but "not in the forefront" of contemporary artists; the manuscript "now so exceptional, was in its day a piece of local everyday art".{{sfn|Schapiro|1980|p=385}} Epstein also challenges Malinkoff's assertion that an antisemitic manuscript would be accepted by its Jewish patrons.{{sfn|Epstein|2011|pp=49–50}} He notes:
Instead, it makes more sense to assume that the griffins' heads were the specific choice of the patrons. Far from being anti-Jewish caricatures, the griffin-headed figures in the Birds' Head Haggadah are dignified portrayals of Jews, full of character and personality. All are going seriously about their business or are posed with stateliness and monumentality in spite of the singular strangeness of their heads.{{sfn|Epstein|2011|p=54}}
==Provenance== [[File:Birds' Head Haggadah at Israel Museum.jpg|275px|right|thumb|The Birds' Head Haggadah on display at the [[Israel Museum]], 2013]] The original [[Patronage|patron]] of the Haggadah is unknown.{{sfn|Hourihane|2012|p=350}} In the 20th century, the manuscript was owned by the family of Johanna Benedikt, who gave it as a wedding present to Benedikt's new husband, German Jewish lawyer and parliamentarian [[Ludwig Marum]].{{sfn|Estrin|2016}}{{sfn|D'Arcy|2016}} Marum reportedly stored the manuscript in his law office.{{sfn|Estrin|2016}} Following his arrest and deportation by the [[Nazi Germany|Nazis]] in 1933, the manuscript disappeared. It resurfaced in 1946 in [[Jerusalem]] when Herbert Kahn, a German Jewish refugee, sold it to the Bezalel National Museum, the predecessor of the [[Israel Museum]], for $600.{{sfn|D'Arcy|2016}} The museum keeps the manuscript on permanent exhibition.{{cite web |url=http://museum.imj.org.il/imagine/galleries/viewItemE.asp?case=26&itemNum=199815|title=The Birds' Head Haggadah|publisher=[[Israel Museum]]|accessdate=3 August 2017}} Shimon Jeselsohn, a law colleague of Marum in Germany who immigrated to Israel after the war, read about the museum's acquisition of the manuscript and connected it with the work that he had seen in Marum's possession. He wrote to Marum's daughter, Elisabeth, who was then living in New York, to tell her of the Haggadah's whereabouts.{{sfn|Estrin|2016}} In 1984 Elisabeth made a trip to Israel and saw the manuscript in the museum; afterwards she wrote a letter to the museum saying that Kahn "had no right to sell" their family's Haggadah, but that the family would allow the museum to keep the Haggadah on exhibit "for the benefit of the public".{{sfn|Estrin|2016}}{{sfn|D'Arcy|2016}} According to her daughter, Elisabeth thought there was no way she could retrieve the manuscript, so she did not try to.{{sfn|Estrin|2016}} ===Ownership dispute=== [[File:Ludwig Marum LMZ039657.jpg|125px|right|thumb|[[Ludwig Marum]]]] In 2016 Marum's grandchildren, led by Marum's 75-year-old grandson Eli Barzilai, began demanding compensation, claiming the Haggadah had been sold without the family's permission.{{cite web |url=http://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/1.782762|title=Jewish Family Renews Fight With Israel Museum Over 'Holocaust-looted' 14th-century Haggadah|agency=Associated Press|work=[[Haaretz]]|date=11 April 2017|accessdate=3 August 2017}} Barzilai engaged the services of [[E. Randol Schoenberg]], a U.S. attorney specializing in the recovery of [[Nazi plunder|Nazi-looted artwork]].{{sfn|Estrin|2016}} According to ''[[Artnet]]'', the compensation demand was "less than" USD$10 million.{{sfn|Estrin|2016}} In addition to financial reimbursement, the family asked for the manuscript to be renamed the "Marum Haggadah". The Israel Museum has acknowledged the family's ownership claim predating World War II.{{sfn|Estrin|2016}} It has requested documentation of ownership between 1933 and 1946, at which point it purchased the Haggadah from Kahn. In late 2016 the Marum family obtained more than 1,000 documents from German historians in [[Karlsruhe]], which depict Kahn as a low-paid schoolteacher in constant need of cash. The family asserted that Kahn somehow obtained the Haggadah without their permission, but that they do not think he stole it. ==Other editions== In 1965/1967 a two-volume color [[facsimile]] edition of the Birds' Head Haggadah was published in Israel by M. Spitzer, bringing the manuscript to international attention.{{sfn|Roth|1969}} In 1997 [[Koren Publishers]], in conjunction with the Israel Museum, published ''The Haggada of Passover: With Pop-Up Spreads'', incorporating illustrations from the Birds' Head Haggadah.{{sfn|Bluemel|Taylor|2012|p=290}} Designed for children, the book is printed on heavy cardstock and incorporates [[Pop-up book|pop-ups]] and pull-tabs for users to manipulate the illustrations of the bird-headed characters reenacting historical and Seder practices. The illustrations include the reenactments of the [[Plagues of Egypt|Ten Plagues]], baking matzo, [[crossing the Red Sea]], drinking the [[Passover Seder#The Four Cups|Four Cups]] at the Passover Seder, and more.{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=csCcl25LzGc|title=The Israel Museum Passover Haggadah with Pop-Up Spreads (video)|publisher=judaicawebstore.com|date=21 February 2012|accessdate=14 September 2017}}{{cite web |url=https://www.jweekly.com/2012/03/30/new-haggadahs-from-the-basics-to-illuminating-storytelling/|title=New haggadahs from the basics to illuminating storytelling from Jonathan Safran Foer|date=30 March 2012|accessdate=14 September 2017|work=[[J. The Jewish News of Northern California|Jweekly]]}} The Haggadah's Hebrew text is supplemented by Koren's English translation.{{sfn|Bluemel|Taylor|2012|p=290}} The pop-up book was reprinted in 2008, and again in 2012. ==Notes== {{notelist}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==Sources== *{{cite book|ref=harv|editor-last=Barash|editor-first=Moshé |editor2-last=Assmann|editor2-first=Jan {{Infobox military installation | name = Castle of Alva | ensign = | ensign_size = | native_name = Castelo de Alva | type = Castle <!-- images --> | image = | caption = <!-- maps and coordinates --> | image_map = | map_caption = Location of the castle within the municipality of [[Freixo de Espada à Cinta]] | pushpin_map = | pushpin_relief = | pushpin_map_caption = | coordinates = | coordinates_footnotes = <!-- location --> | partof = | location = [[Bragança (district)|Bragança]], [[Douro]], [[Norte Region, Portugal]] | nearest_town = | country = [[Portugal]] <!-- stats --> | ownership = [[Portugal|Portuguese Republic]] | operator = | open_to_public = Public | site_area = | built = | used = | builder = | materials = Schist | height = | length = | fate = | condition = | battles = | events = | garrison = | occupants = | website = | footnotes = }} The '''Castle of Alva''' ({{lang-pt|Castelo de Alva}}) is a [[Middle Ages|medieval]] [[castle]] located in the [[Freguesia (Portugal)|civil parish]] of [[Viade de Baixo e Fervidelas]], in the [[Concelho|municipality]] of [[Freixo de Espada à Cinta]], [[Portugal|Portuguese]] [[Bragança District|district of Bragança]].
==History== As part of the [[Kingdom of León|Leonese]] invasion, in June 1212, the first reference to the castle between Freixo de Espada à Cinta and Urros.<ref name="SIPA">{{citation |url=http://www.monumentos.pt/Site/APP_PagesUser/SIPA.aspx?id=477 |title=Castelo de Alva (IPA.00000477/PT010404060006) |publisher=SIPA – Sistema de Informação para o Património Arquitectónico |editor=SIPA |location=Lisbon, Portugal |language=Portuguese |first=Ernesto |last=Jana |first2=Marisa |last2=Costa |year=2001 |accessdate=19 April 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161220152317/http://www.monumentos.pt/Site/APP_PagesUser/SIPA.aspx?id=477 |archivedate=20 December 2016 |df= }}</ref>
By 1236 it was occupied by Leonese forces with the consent of its habitants.<ref name=SIPA/><ref name=IGESPAR/> Shortly after, King D. [[Sancho II of Portugal|Sancho II]] donated the place to the municipality of Freixo "como sua aldeia" (''with its village''), ordering the expulsion of the residents who lived there during the Leonese occupation.<ref name=SIPA/><ref name=IGESPAR/> At the time of the 1258 ''Inquirições'' (''Inquiries'') indicated that King Sancho had transferred the title to Freixo.<ref name=SIPA/>
During the reign of King D. [[Denis of Portugal|Dinis]], the municipality of Alva requested that King ''expand its settlement of 400 residents''.<ref name=SIPA/> But, by 1311, in a letter, the King refused the request, owing to opposition from the municipality of Freixo.<ref name=SIPA/>
Between 1527 and 1532, the village of Alva was not listed in the ''Numeramento'', suggesting that the settlement no longer existed by the end of the 16th century.<ref name=SIPA/>
During the 17th century, António Coelho Gasco, external judge and captain-major of the town of Freixo, described the state of abandonment that the structure, which he referred to as the ''"Antiquario"'' (''antiquary''), during a presentation on his visit to the Archbishop of Braga, D. Rodrigo da Cunha.<ref name=SIPA/> By the end of the same century, Father Carvalho da Costa, referring to the limits of Poiares in the ''Corografia Portuguesa'', included a small list of landmarks; this included the Hermitage of Nossa Senhora de Alva and ''"alongside it the ruined Castle with its walls, where in the past, was founded the Town of Alva"'', remembering that D. Sancho II had deprived the village of its residents.<ref name=SIPA/> Continuing, that he: :''"gave the village to Freixo and later, depopulated and ruined it, remaining only the boat, that navigated the river, with the name of Alva, and the referred Hermitage of Santa Maria, where is annexed a simple benefit of the Royal Patronage"''.<ref name=SIPA/>
==Architecture== The castle is situated in an area of abundant archaeological vestiges; the parish of Poiares is located between the Serra do Marão and Serra de Avões, along the Couro and Douro Rivers in a rural area, situated on a {{convert|700|m|ft}} hilltop dominating the Douro valley.<ref name="IGESPAR">{{citation |url=http://www.patrimoniocultural.pt/pt/patrimonio/patrimonio-imovel/pesquisa-do-patrimonio/classificado-ou-em-vias-de-classificacao/geral/view/72908 |title=Castelo de Alva |publisher=IGESPAR – Instituto de Gestão do Património Arquitectónico e Arqueológico (Portuguese Institute of Architectural and Archaeological Heritage) |year=2013 |first=A. |last=Martin |accessdate=19 April 2016}}</ref> The actually location is covered in vegetation and olive orchards.<ref name=SIPA/>

'''Central Asian art''' is [[visual art]] created in [[Central Asia]] by the largely [[Turkic peoples]] of modern [[Kyrgyzstan]], [[Kazakhstan]], [[Uzbekistan]], [[Turkmenistan]], [[Azerbaijan]], [[Tajikistan]], [[Mongolia]], [[Tibet]], [[Afghanistan]], [[Pakistan]] and parts of China and Russia.<ref name="1a">{{cite book|author=Tamara Talbot Rice|title=Visual Arts|date=July 2011|accessdate=May 17, 2012|publisher=Oxford}}</ref><ref name="1b">{{cite book|author=Fahir İz|title=Central Asian Literature|date=|accessdate=May 17, 2012|publisher=}}</ref> The arts of recent centuries are mainly influenced by [[Islamic art]], but the varied earlier cultures were influenced by the art of China, Persia and Greece, as well as the [[Animal style]] that developed among the nomadic peoples of the [[steppe]]s.<ref name="1c">Encyclopædia Britannica, [http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/102325/Central-Asian-arts Central Asian Arts]. 2012. Retrieved May 17, 2012. Encyclopædia Britannica.</ref> The [[Silk Road transmission of art]], [[Scythian art]], [[Greco-Buddhist art]], [[Serindian art]] and more recently [[Persianate]] culture, are all part of this complicated history.
==References== <references />
