revision.text:
The '''Symphony''' in [[D major]], [[Opus number|Op]]. 24, is the only work in this genre by the [[Bohemia]]n-born composer [[Jan Václav Voříšek]]. He wrote it in 1821 at age 30; he died young, at only 34.
The dedication to [[Aloys von Fuchs]] was inscribed in the composer's own hand on 14 April 1823.<ref>Antony Hodgson, Liner notes from Unicorn recording: [[Philharmonia Orchestra|New Philharmonia Orchestra]] under [[Michael Bialoguski]]</ref>
It is scored for a standard classical orchestra typical of late [[Joseph Haydn|Haydn]] or early [[Ludwig van Beethoven|Beethoven]] symphonies: 2 flutes, 2 oboes, 2 clarinets, 2 bassoons, 2 horns, 2 trumpets, timpani and strings.<ref name=imslp/> Indeed, it has often been compared to early Beethoven, although it was written only six years before that master's death, 16 months after Voříšek. He was a friend of [[Franz Schubert|Schubert]] and may well have been influenced by that composer as well.
The Symphony in D is Voříšek's most famous work, and is the first major [[Czech Republic|Czech]] contribution to the 19th century symphonic literature.<ref>[http://culturecatch.com/music/prague-philharmonia-jiri-belohlavek Culture.catch.com]</ref>
The movements are: * ''Allegro con brio'' * ''Andante'' * Scherzo: ''Allegro ma non troppo'' * Finale: ''Allegro con brio''.<ref name=imslp>[http://imslp.org/wiki/Symphony,_Op.24_(Vo%C5%99%C3%AD%C5%A1ek,_Jan_V%C3%A1clav) IMSLP]</ref>
==Recordings== The Symphony in D has been recorded by: * [[Czech National Symphony Orchestra]] under [[Paul Freeman (conductor)|Paul Freeman]] * [[Czech Philharmonic]] under [[Karel Ančerl]] * [[Deutsche Kammerphilharmonie]] under [[Thomas Hengelbrock]] * [[Philharmonia Orchestra|New Philharmonia Orchestra]] under [[Michael Bialoguski]] * [[Prague Philharmonia]] under [[Jiří Bělohlávek]] * [[Scottish Chamber Orchestra]] under Sir [[Charles Mackerras]] * [[West German Sinfonia Orchestra]] under [[Dirk Joeres]].
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8zkEWN-G64Y&feature=plcp Performance of the Symphony] by Slovak Sinfonietta, conducted Peter Vronský, (Indian Summer in [[Levoča]] Festival, 2011), on [[YouTube]].
{{DEFAULTSORT:Symphony in D (Vorisek)}} [[Category:1821 compositions]] [[Category:Romantic symphonies|Vorisek]] [[Category:Compositions by Jan Václav Voříšek]] [[Category:Compositions in D major]]

revision.comment: Reverted [[WP:AGF|good faith]] edits by [[Special:Contributions/SleepForever|SleepForever]] ([[User talk:SleepForever|talk]]): Cn still required about "nonsensically". ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
{{redirect|Talking dog}} {{For|talking animals in folklore and storytelling|Talking animals in fiction}} {{refimprove|date=January 2012}} A '''talking animal''' or '''speaking animal''' is any non-human animal that can produce sounds or gestures resembling those of a [[human language]]. Several species or groups of animals have developed [[animal communication|forms of communication]] which superficially resemble verbal language, however, these are not defined as language because they lack one or more of the defining characteristics, i.e. [[grammar]], [[syntax]], [[Recursion#Recursion in language|recursion]] and [[Displacement (linguistics)|displacement]]. Researchers have been successful in teaching some animals to make gestures similar to [[sign language]]. However, these animals fail to reach one or more of the criteria accepted as defining language. == Possibility of animal language == [[Image:CleverHans.jpg|thumb|[[Clever Hans]] performing]] The term refers to animals which can imitate (though not necessarily understand) human speech. [[Parrot]]s, for example, repeat things nonsensically through exposure.{{citation needed|reason=This is not necessarily true|date=July 2015}} It is a form of [[anthropomorphism]] to call this human speech, as it has no [[Semantics|semantic grounding]]. Researchers have attempted to teach [[Great ape language|great apes]] (gorillas, chimpanzees, and bonobos) spoken language with poor results as they can only be taught how to say one or a few basic or limited words or phrases or less, and sign language with significantly better results as they can be very creative with various [[sign language|hand signals]] like those of [[deaf|deaf people]].{{citation needed|date=January 2012}} However, even the best communicating great ape has shown an inability to grasp the idea of syntax and grammar, instead communicating at best at the same level as a [[pidgin]] language in humans. They are expressive and communicative, but lack the formality that remains unique to human speech. Modern{{clarify timeframe|date=November 2018}} research shows that the key difference is the animal's lack of asking questions and that formal syntax is merely a superficial detail, however Alex the parrot has been recorded as having asked an existential question.{{cite book | title = Who Asked the First Question? The Origins of Human Choral Singing, Intelligence, Language and Speech | last1 = Jordania | first1=Joseph | isbn = 978-99940-31-81-8 |year = 2006 | publisher = Logos | location = Tbilisi| title-link = Who Asked the First Question? }} There are other differences as well, including poor precision, as shown by Kanzi the bonobo used the lexigram for ''chase'' interchangeably with that for ''get'', though this behavior may not be the same for all animals.{{cite web|author=Kluger, J.|title=Inside the minds of animals|year=2010|publisher=Time}}{{cite news| url=http://content.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,2008867,00.html | work=Time | first=Jeffrey | last=Kluger | title=Inside the Minds of Animals | date=August 5, 2010}} Research supports the idea that the linguistic limitations in animals are due to limited general brainpower (as opposed to lack of a specific module),{{citation needed|date=January 2012}} and that words are created by breaking down sentences into pieces, making grammar more basic than semantics.Francisco Lacerda: A ecological theory of language acquisition == Reported cases by species == === Birds === {{main|Bird vocalisation}} {{main|Talking bird}} * Research done by Dr. [[Irene Pepperberg]] indicates that parrots are capable of speaking in context and with intentional meaning. One of Pepperberg's parrots, [[Alex (parrot)|Alex]], a [[grey parrot]], demonstrated the ability to assemble words out of letters.{{citation needed|date=February 2015}} === Dogs === {{main|Dog communication}} {{See also|Hundesprechschule Asra}} An owner hears a dog making a sound that resembles a phrase says the phrase back to the dog, who then repeats the sound and is rewarded with a treat. Eventually the dog learns a modified version of the original sound. Dogs have limited vocal imitation skills, so these sounds usually need to be shaped by selective attention and social reward.{{cite web | url=http://www.scientificamerican.com/article/fact-or-fiction-dogs-can-talk/| title=Fact or Fiction: Dogs Can Talk |first=Tina | last=Adler | publisher = Scientific American | date = June 10, 2009 | accessdate = February 19, 2015}} *A dog on [[America's Funniest Home Videos]] named Fluffy, made noises that to some viewers resembled "I want my momma" after being asked "Do you want your momma?".{{citation needed|date=August 2013}} Other videos showed other dogs making noises which to some viewers resembling "Run around", "I want it", "I love momma" and "Hello". * Odie, a [[pug]] who produced noises resembling "I love you" on demand, made appearances on several television shows.{{cite web|url=http://www.thetalkingpug.com/|title=the talking pug|accessdate=2008-12-11}} * [[Paranormal]] researcher [[Charles Fort]] wrote in his book ''[[Wild Talents]]'' (1932) of several alleged cases of dogs that could speak English. Fort took the stories from contemporary newspaper accounts. *A husky which produces vocalisations that to some viewers sound like 'no' has appeared in the Daily Mail, the Mirror and the Huffington Post, amongst others.{{cite news| url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2539781/Defiant-husky-Blaze-hates-kennel-learnt-say-no-owner-tries-bed.html | location=London | work=Daily Mail | first=Emma | last=Thomas | title=Defiant husky Blaze hates his kennel so much he learnt how to say no | date=January 15, 2014}} * In 1715 [[Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz]] published an account of his encounter with a talking dog that could pronounce about 30 words.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=UoaoAwAAQBAJ&pg=PT72&lpg=PT72&dq=Don+Talking+Dog#v=onepage&q=Leibniz&f=false|title=Amazing Dogs: A Cabinet of Canine Curiosities|first=Jan|last=Bondeson|date=15 March 2011|publisher=Amberley Publishing Limited|via=Google Books|isbn=9781445609645}} * Don, a German pointer born around the beginning of the 20th century, was a dog that was reputed to be able to pronounce a couple of words in German and became a vaudeville sensation as a result. Although most scientists at the time dismissed Don's capabilities, the author [[Jan Bondeson]] puts forward an argument that Don was genuinely capable of limited human speech and criticises the tests that were performed on Don at the time as having serious methodological flaws.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=UoaoAwAAQBAJ&pg=PT72&lpg=PT72&dq=Don+Talking+Dog#v=onepage&q=Don+Talking+Dog&f=false|title=Amazing Dogs: A Cabinet of Canine Curiosities|first=Jan|last=Bondeson|date=15 March 2011|publisher=Amberley Publishing Limited|via=Google Books|isbn=9781445609645}} * In 1959 a German sheepdog by the name of Corinna living in [[Prague]] spontaneously developed a capability for limited human speech. According to the zoologist Hermann Hartwigg, published under the pseudonym 'Hermann Dembeck', Corinna 'holds the record in modern times for its talking prowess'.{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/?id=WmUTAQAAMAAJ&q=Corinna+Dog+Tuma&dq=Corinna+Dog+Tuma|title=Willingly to school: How animals are taught|publisher=Taplinger Publishing Company |date=2017-06-09}} === Cats === {{main|Cat communication}} * The case of a cat that was videotaped speaking purported human words and phrases such as "Oh my dog", "Oh Long John", "[[Oh Long Johnson]]", "Oh Don piano", "Why I eyes ya", and "All the live long day"{{cite video | url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9LBKVXyrHcw | title=Oh Long Johnson... - talking cat | date=June 11, 2006}} became an [[Internet phenomenon]] in 2006. Footage of this cat, nicknamed Oh Long Johnson from one of the phrases spoken, was featured on ''[[America's Funniest Home Videos]]'' in 1998, and a longer version of the clip (which revealed the animal was reacting to the presence of another cat) was aired in the UK. Clips from this video are prevalent on [[YouTube]]. The cat appeared as a character in "[[Faith Hilling]]", the 226th episode of ''[[South Park]]'', which aired on March 28, 2012. * [[Miles v. City Council of Augusta, Georgia]], in which the court found that the exhibition of a talking cat was considered an occupation for the purposes of municipal licensing law. === Others === * [[Hoover (seal)|Hoover]] was a [[harbor seal]] who repeated common phrases heard around his exhibit at the [[New England Aquarium]], including his name. He appeared in publications like ''[[Reader's Digest]]'' and ''[[The New Yorker]]'', and television programs like ''[[Good Morning America]]''.{{cite web |url=http://www.neaq.org/animals_and_exhibits/exhibits/individual_exhibits/harbor_seals_exhibit/hoover.php |title=Hoover, the Talking Seal |publisher=New England Aquarium |work=Neaq.org |date= |accessdate=2012-01-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120214110807/http://www.neaq.org/animals_and_exhibits/exhibits/individual_exhibits/harbor_seals_exhibit/hoover.php |archivedate=2012-02-14 |df= }} * [[Gef the talking mongoose]] was an alleged talking animal who inhabited a small house on the [[Isle of Man]], off the coast of [[Great Britain]]. Fringe authors believe Gef was a [[poltergeist]], a strange animal or [[Cryptozoology|cryptid]]. Contemporary academics believe it was most likely a [[hoax]].{{cite web | last = Josiffe | first = Christopher | authorlink = | title = Gef the Talking Mongoose | work = Fortean Times | publisher = Dennis Publishing | date = January 2011 | url = http://www.forteantimes.com/features/articles/4915/gef_the_talking_mongoose.html | doi = | accessdate = December 23, 2012}}{{cite book|author1=Chris Berry|author2=So-yŏng Kim|author3=Lynn Spigel|title=Electronic Elsewheres: Media, Technology, and the Experience of Social Space|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rsZ3C011_dgC&pg=PA39|accessdate=19 August 2013|date=January 2010|publisher=U of Minnesota Press|isbn=978-0-8166-4736-1|pages=39–}} * [[Batyr]] (1969–1993), an elephant from [[Kazakhstan]], was reported to have a vocabulary of more than 20 phrases. Recordings of Batyr saying "Batyr is good", "Batyr is hungry", and words such as "drink" and "give" were played on Kazakh state radio in 1980.{{cite web|url=http://www.fortunecity.com/emachines/e11/86/fortean1.html |title=Conversing cows and eloquent elephants |publisher=fortunecity.com |accessdate=2008-12-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080724001159/http://www.fortunecity.com/emachines/e11/86/fortean1.html |archivedate=July 24, 2008 }} * [[Kosik (elephant)|Kosik]] (born 1990) is an elephant able to imitate Korean words.{{cite news |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/10/11/kosik-talking-elephant-at_n_758335.html |title=Kosik, Talking Elephant, Attracts Researchers And Tourists In South Korea |work=Huffington Post |date=October 11, 2010 |accessdate=December 23, 2012}} * Some of the species of [[toothed whales]] like [[dolphins]] and [[porpoises]] such as [[beluga whales]] can imitate the patterns of human speech.{{cite web |url=http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2012/10/23/study-male-beluga-whale-mimics-human-speech.html |title=Study: Male beluga whale mimics human speech |date=23 October 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714191128/http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2012/10/23/study-male-beluga-whale-mimics-human-speech.html |archivedate=14 July 2014 |df= }} [[NOC (whale)|NOC]], a captive beluga whale in the United States Navy's Cold Ops program, could mimic some words well enough to confuse Navy divers on at least one occasion.{{cite web |url=http://www.smithsonianmag.com/science-nature/story-one-whale-who-tried-bridge-linguistic-divide-between-animals-humans-180951437/ |title=The Story of One Whale Who Tried to Bridge the Linguistic Divide Between Animals and Humans| date=June 2014|publisher=Smithsonian Magazine}} * [[John C. Lilly]]'s assistant [[Margaret Howe Lovatt|Margaret Howe]] trained a dolphin named Peter to produce several words, including a credible "Mar-ga-ret". * It is not unusual for [[goat]]s to make noises that sound like syllables from human words. Some videos of this behavior have ended up becoming popular on YouTube. An example from Tennessee of a baby goat seeming to say "what what what?" got over seven million views.[https://news.yahoo.com/blogs/trending-now/is-this-goat-talking-175823260.html Is This Goat Talking? | Yahoo News]
In August, Lyndsey Hyde of Tennessee [https://vine.co/v/OB5j0jdn1Pt posted a video to Vine] featuring a goat that sounds like it is saying "What? What? What?" The 6-second clip went viral with more than 7 million views on the video-sharing app. == See also == * [[Animal cognition]] * [[Animal communication]] * [[Animal language]] * [[Derek Bickerton]] – Animal Communication Systems researcher * [[Human–animal communication]] * [[Human speechome project]] * ''[[Kinship with All Life]]'' – book * [[Vocal learning]] == References == {{reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.bl.uk/listentonature Listen to Nature] "The Language of Birds" includes article and audio samples of "talking" birds * [https://web.archive.org/web/20051227090139/http://www.neaq.org/scilearn/kids/hooveronly.html New England Aquarium's Hoover page] {{Animal communication}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Talking Animal}} [[Category:Ethology]] [[Category:Folklore]] [[Category:Talking animals| ]]

revision.comment: Removed [[WP:NFCC]] violation(s). No valid [[WP:NFUR]] for this page. See [[WP:NFC#Implementation]]. Questions? [[WP:MCQ|Ask here]].
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2016}} [[File:Target-girl Astrid with knife in flight.jpg|thumb|right|Astrid Schollenberger rehearses with top knife thrower Rev Dr David Adamovich. One knife is captured in flight, fractions of a second before impact.]] In [[circus]] and [[vaudeville]] acts, a '''target girl''' is a female assistant in "[[impalement arts|impalement]]" acts such as [[knife throwing]], [[archery]] or [[Exhibition shooting|sharpshooting]]. The assistant stands in front of a target board or is strapped to a moving board and the impalement artist throws knives or shoots projectiles so as to hit the board but miss the assistant. The image or character of the target girl has become an icon in fiction and visual media.
==Introduction== Although some assistants are male there is no common equivalent term for a male assistant. This reflects the fact that, historically at least, female assistants have predominated in the acts in question.<ref>Stanley Brion in the foreword to Adamovich, Heil & Schollenberger, ''A Day on Broadway: The art of being a knife thrower's assistant'', (pub. Turnshare, London, 2005), p.x</ref> The presence of an assistant as a human target provides a powerful element of risk. Without assistants placing themselves in danger these acts would be simple demonstrations of accuracy, but with the potential for injury or death the show is much more dramatic. Target girls often wear revealing costumes, thus adding an element of overt [[Human female sexuality|sexuality]] to an act. In this respect there is some similarity to [[magician's assistant|magicians' assistants]], although there is a distinct difference in that any apparent danger to an assistant in a magic act is mostly an illusion, whereas impalement acts are demonstrations of accuracy, nerve and calculated risk and the danger is real.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/1120219.stm |title = Artist 'undeterred' by crossbow accident |publisher = ''BBC News'' |date = 16 January 2001 |accessdate = 2009-04-27 }}</ref> While some observers have perceived target girls as masochistic or passive and some feminists criticise the concept as [[misogynist]], several target girls have given accounts of themselves as assertive women and portrayed their experiences as empowering (see [[#Target girls as authors|Target girls as authors]]).
Various theories have been put forward to explain the enduring appeal of the target girl. These range from simple awe at the display of steely nerves and complete trust to more complex psychological and philosophical theories. While some point to overtones of [[BDSM|sadomasochistic]] [[erotic]]ism, others cite [[Dramaturgy|dramaturgical]] works and point to parallels with the story arc of the [[hero]] in classic drama.<ref>The most extensive evidence of the debate on this topic is to be found in various online forums, including the ''Dangerous Circus Acts'' groups on Yahoo!</ref> In particular the assistant's performance is said to mirror the plot device of the [[Monomyth#Initiation|hero's ordeal]], in which the hero proves his or her heroic qualities through self-sacrifice or by facing extreme peril.<ref>Dr Joachim Heil PhD, "A short philosophical essay on the art of knife throwing", in Adamovich, Heil & Schollenberger, ''A Day on Broadway'', pp.83-114</ref> [[Jim Steinmeyer]], a noted illusion designer who has written well-regarded books on the history of magic, has identified a fashion for female peril as entertainment in the post-First World War period. Steinmeyer has written that [[P. T. Selbit]]'s stage debut of the ''[[Sawing a woman in half|Sawing Through A Woman]]'' illusion in 1921 marked the beginning of a trend for women as the victims of choice for acts simulating danger or torture. While Steinmeyer focuses on stage magic and attributes some of the trend to practical factors, he also points to a broader pattern in entertainment generally, which he links to social trends. He concludes that: "...beyond practical concerns, the image of the woman in peril became a specific fashion in entertainment".<ref name="hiding">{{cite book |title = Hiding the Elephant: How Magicians Invented the Impossible |first = Jim |last = Steinmeyer |publisher = William Heinemann/Random House |date = 2003 |page = 292 |isbn = 0-434-01325-0 }}</ref> A further view on historical trends is provided by performer and blogger Ula the Painproof Rubbergirl, who has acted as a target girl for New York-based knife thrower The Great Throwdini. In an extensive article on her experiences and philosophical approach to the art she notes: "Knife throwing is an old act. So is high wire. And rodeo. And stone throwing, witch burning, beheading, Roman gladiators, jousting, dog fights,you name it - we, humans, love it. And we love a vulnerable woman. Isn't there something oddly attractive about the woman in danger? I remember seeing lots of soundless black and white movies with a girl tied to the railroad tracks or a girl tied to a sawmill by some evil perverted landlord."<ref name="ula">Ula, [http://www.painproofrubbergirls.com/stories/knife/index.html The Knife Thrower's Assistant] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070812235016/http://www.painproofrubbergirls.com/stories/knife/index.html |date=12 August 2007 }}, painproofrubbergirls.com, (2003)</ref>
==Notable real life target girls== Like [[magicians' assistant]]s, target girls have often suffered the injustice of not receiving the same recognition and billing as their co-performers. Those that have received equal billing have generally been part of husband and wife acts, which are common in this field. Acts that involve a domestic partnership as well as an on-stage one have tended to have greater longevity than pairings where a thrower recruits an assistant as an employee. It has been suggested that this is because the off-stage domestic ties serve to keep the partnership together in the face of the tensions that can occur within such acts. The lack of individual billing for target girls adds to the difficulty of picking out notable examples. The following is therefore a small selection who are distinguished by particular features of their careers rather than a definitive "hall of fame".
* '''Elizabeth Collins''' is almost unique in having effectively ended up with top billing in the knife throwing act she formed with her husband Martin Collins. The couple met and married in their native Hungary at around the time of the outbreak of World War II and began performing together as "Elizabeth and Collins". For their signature stunt they developed an extremely demanding trick that involved Elizabeth spinning on a "[[Wheel of death (Impalement arts)|wheel of death]]" target while her husband balanced on a tightrope and threw knives at her. After the war they settled in Britain and toured clubs and theatres around the world. They were one of the first impalement acts to break into television. Elizabeth retired from performing in the early 1960s and was replaced by their daughter who was also named Elizabeth (although additionally known as Agnes). Elizabeth and Collins performed on ''[[The Ed Sullivan Show]]'' three times and appeared as themselves in an episode of the 1960s spy series ''[[The Avengers (TV series)|The Avengers]]''.<ref>{{cite journal |url = http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=VC&p_theme=vc&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&s_dispstring=Collins%20Vetro&p_field_date-0=YMD_date&p_params_date-0=date:B,E&p_text_date-0=2007&p_field_advanced-0=&p_text_advanced-0=(Collins%20Vetro)&p_perpage=10&p_sort=_rank_:D&xcal_ranksort=4&xcal_useweights=yes |journal = The Columbian |title = Final Salute: Her husband missed her a lot, and that was good |first = Justin |last = Carinci |page = C1 |date = 24 November 2007 |accessdate = 2008-01-28 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url = https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1812489 |title = Elizabeth and Collins |publisher = [[Internet Movie Database]] |accessdate = 2007-03-30}}</ref> *'''Helga and Sylvia Brumbach''' are a mother and daughter who have both been part of a family act that is regarded by many other artists as setting the standard in their field. The Brumbachs, also known as Los Alamos, began with Fritz Brumbach as a knife thrower and whip cracker and his wife Helga as target girl. Later daughter Sylvia joined the act as a second target girl and then son Patrick became a thrower. Fritz and Helga have since retired but Patrick and Sylvia continue the act. Fritz is a [[Guinness World Records|Guinness World Record]] holder for rapid throwing around a live target.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.messershow-losalamos.com |title = Los Alamos Messer-, Lasso- und Peitschen-show |publisher = Patrick Brumbach |accessdate = 2007-03-30}}</ref> * '''Irene Stey''' married into an old established Swiss circus family when she wed Rolf Stey. The couple worked as a knife act called "Two Tornados" between 1965 and 1985 and are notable for being one of only two acts to repeat the combined "wheel of death" and tightrope stunt developed by Elizabeth and Collins. After retiring as a target girl Irene continued in the circus business with an equestrian act.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.zirkus-stey.ch/archiv2007/frames/history/frame_history.html |title = Die Geschichte der Dynastie Stey |publisher = Zirkus Stey |accessdate = 2008-05-10 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071130053527/http://www.zirkus-stey.ch/archiv2007/frames/history/frame_history.html |archivedate = 30 November 2007 |df = dmy-all }}</ref> * '''Barbara Braun''' began performing with her husband Sylvester as the "Wizards of the West" in the early 1940s. Sixty years later the couple were honoured by the International Knifethrowers Hall of Fame with the "Knife Throwing Pioneer Award" and the title "Wild West Duo of the 20th Century".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ikthof.com/IKTHOF/Sylvester%20Braun.htm |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061126033649/http://www.ikthof.com/IKTHOF/Sylvester%20Braun.htm |archive-date=26 November 2006 |title=2003 Knife Throwing Pioneer Award |publisher=International Knife Throwers Hall of Fame |accessdate=2007-03-30 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |url = http://www.throwzini.com/issue_102.html |first = Scott |last = Gracia |journal = The Great Throwzini Newsletter |title = Issue #102 |publisher = Scott Gracia |accessdate = 2007-03-30 }}</ref> * '''Montana Nell''' was the performing name of Pearl Collins who, between 1929 and 1950, toured with her husband Robert Collins in a western arts act under the billing of "Texas Slim and Montana Nell". She was born Pearl Miller and grew up on a farm, which helped her become a highly proficient horse rider. In 1923 she married a man called Seamor Russell with whom she had a daughter named Doris. Seamor died of an illness in 1925 and Pearl went on to marry Collins in 1929. When Doris was 16 she joined her parents' show as a trick rider and sharp shooter named "Little Miss Peggy". Pearl and Robert Collins were posthumously honoured by the International Knifethrowers Hall of Fame in 2006.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ikthof.com/IKTHOF/Bios/texas-slim_montana-nell_2006.htm |title=2006 Pioneer Award |publisher=International Knife Throwers Hall of Fame |accessdate=2007-03-30 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070908110142/http://www.ikthof.com/IKTHOF/Bios/texas-slim_montana-nell_2006.htm |archivedate=8 September 2007 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref> * '''Claude Chantal Blanc''' is an experienced Swiss aerial and tight wire artist who is unusual for working as part of an all-female knife throwing act named ''Risk Ladies''. The thrower was Caroline Haerdi, who currently works in partnership with a male thrower named Arno Black; she as the thrower and he as the target.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.web-art.ch/claude-chantal/englstart.html |title = Claude Chantal Blanc: artist for circus and variété |publisher = WebArt, E. Gehrig & Co |accessdate = 2007-04-11 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070524180905/http://www.web-art.ch/claude-chantal/englstart.html |archivedate = 24 May 2007 |df = dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.claude-chantal.ch/high/en/index.html |title = Official website |publisher = Claude-Chantal Blanc |accessdate = 2007-04-11 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070205045959/http://www.claude-chantal.ch/high/en/index.html |archivedate = 5 February 2007 |df = dmy-all }}</ref> * '''Tina Nagy''' Is a dancer and aerial artist who featured as a target girl in the 2007 season of the [[NBC]] television series ''[[America's Got Talent]]''. Nagy, who is of Hungarian descent but grew up in Connecticut, performed with knife thrower The Great Throwdini. Her interest in the impalement arts began through working as a target girl for bullwhip artist Robert Dante. She has sought to produce a performance artform that combines dance and whip cracking.<ref>{{Cite journal |first = Jon |last = Tevlin |title = The bullwhipper and the bellydancer |journal = Star Tribune (Minneapolis) |date = 27 June 2004 }}</ref> * '''Ekaterina Sknarina''' is a model, actress, contortionist, aerial artist and former international gymnast. She was born in Russia and competed at world championship level for the Russian rhythmic gymnastics team. She later trained as an aerial artist with [[Cirque du Soleil]]. After re-locating to New York she began working as a [[contortionist]] in the burgeoning new burlesque scene. She also began working as a model and appeared in magazines including [[FHM]], One World, and [[GQ]]. She added the role of target girl to her portfolio after meeting knife thrower The Great Throwdini. In 2005 she was one of the stars of the off-Broadway show ''Maximum Risk'', during which she helped set two world records for the number of knives thrown around a human target in a minute. She was Miss [[Coney Island]] 2007. She appears in the movie ''[[Across the Universe (film)|Across the Universe]]'' (2007) and was featured in promotional posters for it.<ref name="imdb-katya">{{IMDb name |id=2772482|name = Ekaterina Sknarina}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |url = http://www.curtainup.com/maximumrisk.html |first = Amanda |last = Cooper |title = A Curtain Up Review: Maximum Risk |journal = Curtain Up |date = 3 July 2005}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url = http://knifethrower.com/maximumriskonline/bios.html |title = Performer Bios |publisher = Rev Dr David Adamovitch |accessdate = 2008-05-23}}</ref>
===Target girls as authors=== A very small and select group of women are notable for having used personal experience to write about the impalement arts from the point of view of the target girl. They include: * '''Astrid Schollenberger''' a middle-aged German single mother with a master's degree in philosophy and a regular job who, at the suggestion of her boyfriend Dr Joachim Heil, volunteered as a target girl for knife thrower Dr David Adamovich (aka The Great Throwdini). Schollenberger worked with Adamovich for a show in New York in 2002 where he first publicly performed the "[[Wheel of death (Impalement arts)|Wheel of death]]" stunt. Later Schollenberger, Adamovich and Heil wrote a book about the experience titled ''A Day on Broadway: The art of being a knife thrower's assistant''.<ref>Adamovich, Heil & Schollenberger, ''[http://www.knifethrower.net A Day on Broadway: The art of being a knife thrower's assistant] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070415193805/http://www.knifethrower.net/ |date=15 April 2007 }}'', Turnshare (London, 2005), {{ISBN|1-903343-73-9}}</ref> * '''[[Ronnie Claire Edwards]]''' is an American actress born in 1933. She is best known for the role of "Corabeth Walton Godsey" in the series ''[[The Waltons]]'' (1972 - 1981). Her substantial and often quirky career is recalled in an autobiography titled ''The Knife Thrower's Assistant: Memoirs of a Human Target''.<ref>[[Ronnie Claire Edwards]], ''The Knife Thrower's Assistant: Memoirs of a Human Target'', Hawk Publishing Group, (October 2000), {{ISBN|1-930709-16-1}}</ref> * '''Ula the Painproof Rubbergirl''' started as one half of a duo called The Painproof Rubbergirls who did [[contortion]] and various [[sideshow|sideshow-type]] stunts, such as the [[Bed of nails]]. After her partner left for other work, Ula continued as a solo performer doing various aerial acts as well as a signature routine that involves contortion feats on a bed of swords. In 2003 she worked as a target girl for Dr David Adamovich (aka The Great Throwdini) and later wrote a lengthy article about the act and the philosophy behind her part in it.<ref name="ula"/> Ula was featured as a target girl in the US edition of FHM magazine in March 2006.<ref>{{Cite journal |url = http://knifethrower.com/images/fhm.gif |title = World of Knives: Blade Target |journal = FHM |date = March 2006}}</ref>
===Celebrity target girls=== A small group of target girls are notable for the fact that they are well known celebrities who performed the role for charitable purposes or other reasons apart from their main career. These are examples of the target girl, rather than the thrower, being the main individual in the act. The annual ''[[Circus of the Stars]]'' television special, made by [[CBS]] between 1977 and 1994, provided a number of examples. They include: * '''[[Lynda Carter]]''', the actress best known as television's [[Wonder Woman]], appeared as a target girl on the very first ''Circus of the Stars'' in January 1977, with actor [[David Janssen]] throwing knives at her.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.wonderland-site.com/html/miscel/appear/WLA-00016.htm |title = ''Lynda Carter: Other TV appearances 1956-1979: 016 The Circus of the Stars 1979'' |publisher = Wonderland - The Ultimate Wonder Woman site |accessdate = 2007-03-30 }}</ref><ref name="carter_note">It has been suggested that Janssen and Carter's act was faked using a trick target board that worked in a manner similar to the method exposed on the ''Masked Magician'' television show. Professional throwers have observed that Janssen's throwing style is wrong and would result in wildly inaccurate throws if he were really throwing knives. This seems to be the only occasion when a knife throwing act was faked on ''Circus of the Stars''. All the other occasions when the show included a knife act involved professional throwers and the genuine nature of the acts has been confirmed through study of video footage.</ref> * Actress and model '''[[Ann Turkel]]''' performed the role of target girl for knife thrower Skeeter Vaughan in the second ''Circus of the Stars'' in December 1977.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://kristymcnichol.net/circusofthestars2.htm |title = Kristy McNichol on TV |publisher = J Wilson |accessdate = 2007-11-21}}</ref> * '''[[Charlene Tilton]]''', the actress best known for her role in the television series ''Dallas'', famously appeared in a gold bikini as a target girl for knife thrower Skeeter Vaughan in the 1979 ''Circus of the Stars''.<ref>{{cite web |url = https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0242372 |title = Circus of the Stars #4 |publisher = Internet Movie Database |accessdate = 2007-04-04}}.</ref> * '''[[Sally Kellerman]]''', the actress who played [[Margaret Houlihan|Major Margaret "Hot Lips" Houlihan]] in the film ''[[MASH (film)|MASH]]'', appeared as a target girl for knife thrower Larry Cisewski on the 1981 ''Circus of the Stars''. She was seen holding balloons for Cisewski to burst and also braved being spun around on his "Devil's door" target board as he planted knives around her.<ref>{{IMDb name|id=001419|name=Sally Kellerman}}</ref> * '''[[Linda Blair]]''', the actress who rose to fame as a child star in ''The Exorcist'', appeared as a target girl for knife thrower Paul Lacross on ''Circus of the Stars'' in 1983.<ref name="lindablair">Linda Blair appeared on the show three times, in 1982, 1983 and 1990. See {{IMDb name|id=0000304|name = Linda Blair}}. She was pictured in costume and holding a set of throwing axes on the cover of the 18–24 December 1983 issue of ''TV News'' magazine</ref> * Actress '''[[Britt Ekland]]''' appeared as a target girl for knife thrower Fritz Brumbach on ''Circus of the Stars'' in 1986. * Television presenter and actress '''[[:de:Ursula von Manescul|Ursula von Manescul]]''' appeared as a target girl on the annual German charity circus show ''[[Stars in der Manege#Other versions and variations|Stars in der Manege]]'' in 1967. She performed with a duo called The Williams Boys.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.br-online.de/land-und-leute/thema/manege/seite2.xml |title=Vier Jahrzehnte Zirkuszauber |publisher=BR online |accessdate=2008-02-08 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080109161400/http://www.br-online.de/land-und-leute/thema/manege/seite2.xml |archivedate=9 January 2008 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref> * Actress '''[[Simone Thomalla]]''' was a target girl for world-record breaking impalement artist Patrick Brumbach in the final edition of the German television charity show ''Stars in der Manege'', recorded in December 2008. During the act she rode a rotating target board as Brumbach threw knives around her and she also held out targets for him to cut with a whip.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.augsburger-allgemeine.de/Home/Nachrichten/Bayern/Artikel,-messerwerfer-brumbach-30012009-_arid,1467800_regid,2_puid,2_pageid,4289.html |title = Glück oder Können? Patrick Brumbach spielt mit den Messern |publisher = Augsburger Allgemeine |accessdate = 2010-09-06 }}</ref>
==Fictional and artistic representation== The mixture of peril, nerve and sexuality inherent in the idea of a target girl has proved attractive to writers, artists, moviemakers and television executives.
===Movie and television===
There are many instances of target girls as iconic or emblematic images in film and television. The most notable movie example is the character Adele portrayed by [[Vanessa Paradis]] in the film ''[[Girl on the Bridge]]'' (1999), in which the knife throwing act is at the centre of the plot and serves as a powerful erotic metaphor.
Other examples include: * The fourth season of the television series ''[[Bones (TV series)|Bones]]'', featured an episode (first aired in 2009) in which title character [[Temperance "Bones" Brennan]] goes undercover as a target girl with Special Agent [[Seeley Booth]] as a knife-thrower. * [[Cameron Diaz]]'s character Jenny Everdeane acts as a target girl in a scene in the film ''[[Gangs of New York]]'' (2002) which was used in promotional clips.<ref>{{cite web |url = https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0217505 |title = Gangs of New York |publisher = Internet Movie Database |accessdate = 2007-03-27}}</ref> * In the television series ''[[Nikki (TV series)|Nikki]]'', an episode aired in 2001 featured the characters played by [[Nikki Cox]] and [[Susan Egan]] taking jobs as target girls.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.tv.com/nikki/show/45/episode_guide.html |title = Nikki: Season 1: 11. The Jupiter and Mary Chain |publisher = TV.com |accessdate = 2007-03-28 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080208204250/http://www.tv.com/nikki/show/45/episode_guide.html |archivedate = 8 February 2008 |df = dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.susanegan.net/fans/gallery.htm |title=The Many Moods of Mary - Susan on the dance set of Nikki |publisher=Susan Egan |accessdate=2007-03-28 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070103003416/http://www.susanegan.net/fans/gallery.htm |archivedate=3 January 2007 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref> * The television play ''The Act'' (1987) revolved around a knife throwing act and a girl who applies for a job as the assistant. It was made for the [[BBC]] and was a co-production involving the [[Royal College of Art]]. It starred Caroline Embling and Bill Rourke. Real life knife thrower Jay Ruffley provided throwing skills in one scene and also appeared as the owner of a club.<ref>''The Act'' was 25 minutes long and was originally transmitted on BBC2 on 18 August 1987 at 10.20pm. See details at {{cite web |url = http://ftvdb.bfi.org.uk/sift/title/126893 |title = ''The Act'' |publisher = The British Film Institute database |accessdate = 2007-03-30 }}</ref><ref>Jay Ruffley sometimes performed under the name Cetan Mani. See {{cite web |url = http://www.ikthof.com/IKTHOF/james-ruffley_2006.htm |title = '' 2006 International Achievement Award'' |publisher = International Knife Throwers Hall of Fame |accessdate = 2007-03-30 }} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.mbagency.co.uk/clients/rourke.html |title = ''Bill Rourke'' |publisher = MBA Agency |accessdate = 2007-03-30}}</ref> * [[Courteney Cox]]'s character in the 1987 television movie ''If it's Tuesday it still must be Belgium'' becomes a target girl in a circus knife throwing act.<ref>{{cite web |url = https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0093242 |title = If it's Tuesday it still must be Belgium |publisher = Internet Movie Database |accessdate = 2007-03-27}}</ref> * In the movie ''Bronco Billy'' (1980), actresses [[Sondra Locke]] and Tessa Richarde are both seen as target girls for a sharpshooter and knife thrower played by [[Clint Eastwood]]. Locke's role in the act is central to the plot.<ref>{{cite web |url = https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0080472 |title = Bronco Billy |publisher = Internet Movie Database |accessdate = 2007-03-27}}</ref> * In the television series ''[[Charlie's Angels]]'', [[Cheryl Ladd]]'s character [[Kris Munroe]] goes undercover as a target girl in an episode titled "Circus of Terror" (1977). * The spy thriller ''Masquerade'' (1965) features [[Marisa Mell]] as a target girl named Sophie.<ref>{{cite web |url = https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0059433 |title = Masquerade |publisher = Internet Movie Database |accessdate = 2007-04-10 }}</ref><ref>For a publicity still see {{cite web |url = http://www.knifethrower.com/images/TGs/marisamell.jpg |title = Masquerade promo picture |publisher = ''Knifethrower.com'' |accessdate = 2007-04-10 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070928104124/http://www.knifethrower.com/images/TGs/marisamell.jpg |archivedate = 28 September 2007 |df = dmy-all }}</ref> * Target girls were iconic figures in a series of horror films set in circuses that were made in the 1960s. These include: ** ''Circus of Horrors'' (1960), in which Vanda Hudson played a target girl called Magda von Meck.<ref>{{cite web |url = https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0053717 |title = Circus of Horrors |publisher = Internet Movie Database |accessdate = 2007-03-27}}</ref> ** ''Circus of Fear'' (1966), which features British actress Margaret Lee as an assistant facing danger in a knife act.<ref>{{cite web |url = https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0060865 |title = Circus of Fear |publisher = Internet Movie Database |accessdate = 2007-03-27}}</ref> ** ''Berserk!'' (1967), in which [[Judy Geeson]] played a target girl in a circus knife act.<ref>{{cite web |url = https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0061398 |title = Berserk! |publisher = Internet Movie Database |accessdate = 2007-03-27}}</ref> * The film ''Phantom of the Rue Morgue'' (1954) has an early scene featuring one of the female leads as a target girl.<ref>{{cite web |url = https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0047348 |title = Phantom of the Rue Morgue (1954) |publisher = Internet Movie Database |accessdate = 2007-04-10 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.knifethrower.com/images/TGs/phantomruemorgue.jpg |title=Phantom of Rue Morgue promo picture |publisher=''Knifethrower.com'' |accessdate=2007-04-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070628155859/http://www.knifethrower.com/images/TGs/phantomruemorgue.jpg |archivedate=28 June 2007 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title = Phantom of Rue Morgue (1954) reviews |publisher = amazon.com |isbn=0790736047}}</ref> * In "Lucy Tells the Truth" (1953), an episode of the television series ''[[I Love Lucy]]'', a white lie leads to [[Lucille Ball]]'s character ending up as the assistant in a knife act. * In the [[Alice in Chains|Alice In Chains]] video "I Stay Away," a knife thrower accidentally kills his target girl when flies distract him and throw off his aim.
===Theatre=== The play ''Pin Cushion'', by Clay McLeod Chapman is based around a husband and wife knife throwing act and consists of the target girl delivering a monologue while her husband throws knives around her. It was performed as part of Chapman's ''Pumpkin Pie Show'' at The Red Room Theatre, New York, in May and June 2002. The performance involved a genuine knife throwing act, with actress Niabi Caldwell as the target girl and professional knife thrower Dr. David Adamovich (aka The Great Throwdini) playing her husband.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.theatermania.com/content/news.cfm/story/2259 |first = Dan |last = Bacalzo |title = The Pumpkin Pie Show in Big Top |publisher = Theatermania |accessdate = 2007-03-30}}</ref>
===Photography===
The target girl has also been used as an image in fashion and art photography. Examples include: * Model [[Karen Elson]] is seen spinning on a "wheel of death" target in a picture by photographer [[Steven Meisel]] that formed part of a series titled ''"The Greatest Show on Earth"'' in the April 2007 issue of the Italian edition of ''[[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue]]'' magazine.<ref name="elson">{{Cite journal |url=http://community.livejournal.com/foto_decadent/1517627.html |first=Steven |last=Meisel |title=The Greatest Show on Earth |journal=Vogue Italia |publisher=Condé Nast Publications |date=April 2007 |accessdate=2007-06-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080513154836/http://community.livejournal.com/foto_decadent/1517627.html |archivedate=13 May 2008 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> * Model [[Kate Moss]] appeared on a "wheel of death" target in two of a series of fashion photos by Mert Alas and Marcus Piggott in the April 2006 issue of ''W'' magazine.<ref>{{Cite journal |url = http://www.style.com/w/feat_story/030706 |last = Alas & Piggott |title = Kate Moss: performance |journal = W Magazine |publisher = Style.com |date = April 2006 |accessdate = 2009-04-13 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060423041507/http://www.style.com/w/feat_story/030706 |archivedate = 2006-04-23}}</ref> * Actress [[Jennifer Ellison]] appeared strapped to a "wheel of death" target and surrounded by knives in the UK edition of ''Maxim'' magazine in 2005. The picture was reproduced in the ''[[Daily Star (United Kingdom)|Daily Star]]'' newspaper on 1 December 2005.<ref>{{Cite journal |url = http://www.maximmag.co.uk/maximgirls/covergirls/2858/jennifer_ellison.html |title = Jennifer Ellison: Ell on Earth |journal = Maxim (UK) |publisher = Maxim magazines |date = 2005 |accessdate = 2007-03-28}}</ref> * Drummer [[Meg White]] appeared as a target girl on a "wheel of death" target in a photo of [[The White Stripes]] by Annie Leibovitz in 2003. The picture was part of a series that appeared in a book and an exhibition, both titled ''Annie Leibovitz: American Music''.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.andrewsmithgallery.com/exhibitions/annieleibovitz/americanmusic/index.htm |title = Annie Leibovitz: American Music |publisher = Andrew Smith Gallery, San Francisco |accessdate = 2007-03-28 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite book |first = Annie |last = Leibovitz |title = Annie Leibovitz: American Music |publisher = Random House/Jonathon Cape |date = 2003 |isbn = 0-224-07271-4}}</ref> * Singer and musician [[Shakira]] appeared standing against a target with knives around her in a photo in the April 2002 issue of ''[[FHM]]'' magazine (UK edition). * Actress [[Goldie Hawn]] appeared in a circus costume strapped to a "wheel of death" target for a photoshoot in 1990 that was later featured in Rolling Stone magazine in 2001.<ref name="hawn_fotopic">{{cite web |url = http://goldiehawn.fotopic.net/p34368897.html |title = 2nd September 2006 Posed |publisher = fotopic.net |accessdate = 2007-11-06 }}{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
* The cover of ''[[Stick It to Ya]]'', the debut album by heavy metal band [[Slaughter (band)|Slaughter]], was infamous for featuring a photo of former ''[[Playboy]]'' playmate [[Laurie Carr]] wearing a swimsuit, strapped to a target board and surrounded by knives. The cover of a subsequent release, ''[[Stick It Live]]'', featured an image apparently from the same shoot as the first but this time showing the target girl walking towards the target board hand-in-in-hand with a knife thrower.
===Literature=== * [[Steven Millhauser]]'s short story ''The Knife Thrower'' features a thrower who specialises in nicking those who stand at the target board for him, including his female assistant. It was published as part of a collection that bears the same title. At least one edition features as its cover a painting of a girl standing in front of a target board.<ref> {{Cite book |first = Steven |last = Millauser |title = The Knife Thrower |publisher = Phoenix Press |date = December 1999 |isbn = 0-7538-0821-8}}</ref> * The relationship between a target girl and a circus knifethrower is the central motif in the poem cycle ''Das Mädchen und der Messerwerfer'' published in 1997 by noted German poet [[Wolf Wondratschek]].<ref name="institut-buchgestaltung"> {{cite web |url=http://www.institut-buchgestaltung.de/joomla/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=96&Itemid=39 |title=Das Mädchen und der Messerwerfer |publisher=Institut fur Buchgestaltung, Bielefeld |accessdate=2010-09-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719044157/http://www.institut-buchgestaltung.de/joomla/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=96&Itemid=39 |archivedate=19 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> * The novel ''Knives of Desire'' by [[Marion Zimmer Bradley]] (writing under the pen name Morgan Ives) is about a woman who becomes involved in a lesbian relationship after joining a circus to be the target girl for a female knife thrower.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.abebooks.co.uk/servlet/BookDetailsPL?bi=65853267&AID=9467007&PID=555228 |publisher = AbeBooks.co.uk |title = Book details: Knives of Desire |accessdate = 2007-09-23 }}</ref> The cover of the original edition, published in 1966, shows two women in skimpy bikinis, one standing against a target board and the other throwing a knife.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.knifethrower.com/cartoon.html |title = cartoon |publisher = knifethrower.com |accessdate = 2007-09-23 }}</ref>
===Music=== * [[Tom Waits]]'s song "Circus" from his 2004 album ''[[Real Gone (album)|Real Gone]]'' features a knife throwing act as part of the eponymous travelling show. * [[Gretchen Peters]] uses the target girl as a central metaphor in her song ''Woman on the Wheel'', which was debuted on her 2010 tour in support of her ''Circus Girl'' album. She later released a recorded version on her 2012 album ''Hello Cruel World''.
==See also== * [[Impalement arts]] * [[Magician's assistant]] * [[Damsel in distress]]
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==Further reading== * Adamovich, Heil & Schollenberger, ''A Day on Broadway: The art of being a knife thrower's assistant'', Turnshare (London, 2005), {{ISBN|1-903343-73-9}}, * Ula the Painproof Rubber Girl, "[https://web.archive.org/web/20070812235016/http://www.painproofrubbergirls.com/stories/knife/index.html The Knife Thrower's Assistant]", an article from the point of view of a target girl (2003) * Tricia Vita, "[https://web.archive.org/web/20070415054848/http://www.nypress.com/15/52/nyc/nyc1.cfm Knifethrower: Target Girls]", an article at ''New York Press''.

revision.text:
{{italic title}} [[File:Jan_Steen_-_Het_Driekoningenfeest.jpg|thumb|290px]] '''''The Bean Feast''''' is a c.1668 painting of a [[bean-feast]] by [[Jan Steen]], now in the [[Gemäldegalerie Alte Meister (Kassel)]].
==Sources== *{{de icon}} Museum:„Gemäldegalerie Alte Meister Schloss Wilhelmshöhe“: Georg Westermann Verlag. Braunschweig, 2. Auflage 1982 ISSN:0341-8634
{{DEFAULTSORT:Bean Feast}} {{17C-painting-stub}} [[category:Paintings of the Gemäldegalerie Alte Meister (Kassel)]] [[category:Paintings by Jan Steen]] [[category:1668 paintings]] [[category:Dogs in art]] [[category:Food and drink paintings]]

{{Infobox film | name = Traceroute | image = Traceroute_-_poster.png | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Johannes Grenzfurthner]] | writer = Johannes Grenzfurthner | narrator = Johannes Grenzfurthner | music = | country = Austria, United States | language = English, German | producer = Johannes Grenzfurthner, Andreas Reisenbauer, [[Heather Kelley]], Guenther Friesinger | cinematography = Eddie Codel | released = {{Film date|2016|04|28|NYC Independent Film Festival}} | runtime = 120 minutes | studio = [[monochrom]], Reisenbauer Film | distributor = [[monochrom]], Reisenbauer Film | budget = }} '''''Traceroute''''' is a 2016 Austrian/American documentary film directed by [[Johannes Grenzfurthner]]. The autobiographical documentary and [[road movie]] deals with the history, politics and impact of [[nerd]] culture. Grenzfurthner calls his film a "personal journey into the uncharted depths of nerd culture, a realm full of dangers, creatures and more or less precarious working conditions",{{cite web|url=http://www.heise.de/tp/artikel/47/47614/1.html|title=Über den Raum in die Zeit|first=Peter|last=Mühlbauer|website=Telepolis|accessdate=31 August 2018}} an attempt to "chase the ghosts of nerddom's past, present and future."{{cite web|url=https://laughingsquid.com/traceroute-a-nerds-eye-view-of-a-fascinating-road-trip-across-the-united-states/|title='Traceroute’, A Nerd’s Eye View of a Fascinating Road Trip Across the United States|date=2 December 2015|publisher=|accessdate=31 August 2018}} The film was co-produced by art group [[monochrom]] and Reisenbauer Film. It features music by [[Kasson Crooker]], Hans Nieswandt, and many others. ==Concept== Artist and self-declared [[nerd]] [[Johannes Grenzfurthner]] is documenting his personal road trip from the West Coast to the East Coast of the United States, to introduce the audience to places and people that shaped and inspired his art and politics. Traceroute is a reflection on Grenzfurthner's own roots of nerddom, and "On the Road style romp across the United States as he visits icons of the counterculture, the outré, and the generally questionable."{{cite web|url=http://www.furtherfield.org/features/reviews/traceroute-%E2%80%93-personal-journey-uncharted-depths-nerd-culture|title=Review on Furtherfield; March 11, 2016|publisher=|accessdate=31 August 2018}} Grenzfurthner summarizes the concept in an interview for [[Boing Boing]]: "It is a film on biographies and obsessions and spaces of possibility – in other words something between loving embrace and merciless vivisection. Maintaining a critical meta-outlook was just as important to me as abandoning myself to unfathomable stammerings of adoration. And that all works for one simple reason: because I take a step forward, introducing myself and confessing my guilt like in Alcoholics Anonymous, only to then take off and visit the best whiskey distilleries. In my case these destinations are not whiskey makers, but people and places and symbols of a very special pop culture."{{cite web|url=http://boingboing.net/2016/04/14/the-story-of-traceroute-about.html|title=The story of Traceroute, about a Leitnerd's quest|date=14 April 2016|publisher=|accessdate=31 August 2018}} On [[Film Threat]] he adds: "It was important for me to take nerddom apart, not only analyzing it, but also excavating its potential for greatness."{{cite web|url=http://filmthreat.com/interviews/johannes-grenzfurthner-is-kinda-nerdy/|title=Johannes Grenzfurthner is Kinda Nerdy – Film Threat|website=filmthreat.com|accessdate=31 August 2018}} The film incorporates art and illustrations by James Brothwell, Bonni Rambatan, [[Michael Marrak]], Karin Frank, Ben Lawson, Michael Zeltner, Josh Ellingson and [[eSeL]] in a cinematic collage that draws inspiration from 1990s [[fanzine]] and [[Punk subculture|punk]] aesthetics, [[Bulletin board system|BBS]] culture, [[ANSI art]] and [[fantastic art]].[http://pressplay.at/2016/03/14/traceroute/ Review on Press Play by Marco Rauch, March 14, 2016] UK Film Review's Hannah Sayer summarizes the artistic style of the film in her review: "There is a real sense that this is a collaborative exploration of creativity: of the old and the new, the past and the present, and the traditional and the digital. The use of photography and drawings interspersed between the interviews with various people associated with nerd culture shows an artistic approach to the material and these images act as reflective snapshots of moments in time, reinforcing the importance of looking back to the past as well as looking forward to the future of the digital age."[http://www.ukfilmreview.co.uk/#!Traceroute-documentary-review/cu0l/5730ed7a0cf20cbfb2963dc0 UK Film Review, May 9, 2016] ==Cast== [[File:Traceroute--Johannes Grenzfurthner and Matt Winston.jpg|thumb|Traceroute: Johannes Grenzfurthner and Matt Winston talk about Stan Winston and special effects]] Traceroute features interviews with [[Matt Winston]], [[Sandy Stone (artist)|Sandy Stone]], [[Bruce Sterling]], [[Jason Scott]], Christina Agapakis, [[Trevor Paglen]], Ryan Finnigan, Kit Stubbs, [[V. Vale]], Sean Bonner, Allison Cameron, Josh Ellingson, Maggie Mayhem, [[Paolo Pedercini]], Steve Tolin, Dan Wilcox, [[Jon Lebkowsky]], Jan "Varka" Mulders (of [[Bad Dragon]]), Adam Flynn, Abie Hadjitarkhani, Kelly Poots, and some special guest appearances (e.g. [[National Park Service|NPS]] spokesperson Vickie Carson, hacker Nick Farr and cultural curator [[Scott Beale (cultural curator)|Scott Beale]]). Metronaut writes: "Traceroute offers deep insights into the world of nerddom. A woman who creates cheese from bacteria on sweaty feet. A man who wants to construct a giant network of independent Geiger counters. Or a sex worker who identifies as a nerd. The multitude of topics and people shows how being a nerd is not restricted to programming and computers."{{cite web|url=https://www.metronaut.de/2016/02/traceroute-von-nerd-zu-nerd/|title=Traceroute: Von Nerd zu Nerd - Metronaut.de|website=www.metronaut.de|accessdate=31 August 2018}} ==Production== ===Writing=== Grenzfurthner performed a [[stand-up]] show called ''Schicksalsjahre eines Nerds'' at Vienna's Rabenhof Theater in 2014. Parts of this show form the basis of Traceroute.{{cite web|url=http://derstandard.at/2000007033569/Pornos-und-tote-Huehner|title=Pornos und tote Hühner|author=Dorian Waller|work=derStandard.at}} The basic script, although many scenes and interviews were improvised, was written by Johannes Grenzfurthner. The film's main language is English, but features archival footage in German. ===Filming=== Principal photography commenced on March 5, 2015 and ended March 27, 2015.{{cite web|url=http://www.imdb.com/title/tt4490762/|title=Traceroute|publisher=|accessdate=31 August 2018|via=www.imdb.com}} The film can be considered [[microfilmmaking]] and [[guerrilla filmmaking]]. ===Sound design=== Daniel Hasibar and Christian Staudacher created the sound design and audioscape underlying Grenzfurthner's narration. ==Music== The film features music by Peter Barnett, [[Kasson Crooker]], Damien Di Fede, Matthew Huffaker, Brady Leo, [[Vera Lynn]], [[Kevin MacLeod (musician)|Kevin MacLeod]], Hans Nieswandt, Roger Sandega, Eric Skiff, among others. ==Distribution== The film's World Premiere took place at NYC Independent Film Festival on April 28, 2016.{{cite web|url=https://www.nycindieff.com/session/traceroute|title=NYC Independent Film Festival - Sessions|first=|last=http://bradmaxs.com|website=www.nycindieff.com|accessdate=31 August 2018}} The European Premiere took place at ''DOK.fest Munich'' ([[Internationales Dokumentarfilmfestival München]]) on May 13, 2016.[https://www.dokfest-muenchen.de/films/view/8105 Traceroute at DOK.fest Munich 2016] Various film festivals and conventions (like ''[[Hackers on Planet Earth]]'' 2016, ''[[Gen Con]]'' 2016, the ''European Media Arts Festival'' 2016{{cite web|url=http://www.emaf.de/deutsch/timetable/traceroute.html|title=Traceroute at EMAF 2016|publisher=|accessdate=31 August 2018}} in [[Osnabrück]], the ''[[Dutch Design Week]]'' 2016, the ''[[NRW-Forum]]'' 2016, ''Print Screen Festival'' 2016{{cite web|url=http://www.printscreenfestival.com/#!traceroute/c6xy|title=Print Screen Festival|website=Print Screen Festival|accessdate=31 August 2018}} in [[Tel Aviv]], ''FrackFest'' 2016, ''Norwich Radical Film Festival'', the [[Chaos Communication Congress]] 2016, [[Guangzhou International Documentary Film Festival]] 2016) have screened the film.[https://www.monochrom.at/traceroute/ List of screenings on Traceroute's homepage] The film had a theatrical release in Austria in 2016. Traceroute was digitally released on March 21, 2017.{{cite web|url=https://vimeo.com/ondemand/traceroute|title=Watch Traceroute Online - Vimeo On Demand|first=|last=monochrom|date=27 November 2015|publisher=|accessdate=31 August 2018|via=Vimeo}}{{cite web|url=http://www.ots.at/presseaussendung/OTS_20170321_OTS0004/preisgekroente-nerd-dokumentation-traceroute-digital-veroeffentlicht|title=Preisgekrönte Nerd-Dokumentation "Traceroute" digital veröffentlicht|publisher=|accessdate=31 August 2018}} ==Reception== ===Critical response=== Reviews of the film have been positive. Bradley Gibson of ''[[Film Threat]]'' gives Traceroute 10/10 points and writes: "Traceroute is the most fun I've ever had watching a documentary. If you're a nerd (and you are) this is the road trip you've always wanted to take with your smartest, geekiest friend. You're not going to want to come home. It's Cosmos. It's DragonCon on wheels. It's your favorite sex fantasy. It's alcohol soaked nonviolent subversive protest mobile and WiFi linked. It's ''On The Road'' updated with tech, science, pseudoscience, sex, and fandom."{{cite web|url=http://filmthreat.com/reviews/traceroute|title=Traceroute – Film Threat|website=filmthreat.com|accessdate=31 August 2018}} [[Mental Floss]]' Chris Higgins writes about Traceroute: "As many nerds have noticed, there's a glut of nerd-positive documentaries out there, but they tend to be either too self-serious, or too focused on the trappings of fandom to actually say much. Traceroute manages to be a real film, with humor and true insight (sometimes called out for us—and delightfully nullified—with a blinking 'INSIGHT' faux-HTML tag onscreen), primarily because it focuses on Grenzfurthner's personal journey, and he doesn't take himself too seriously. Let's put that another way: The director uses himself and a handful of subjects to create his story, and that specificity—coupled with his playfulness—makes it work. At one point he licks the chrome head of a Terminator prop. Then he licks a zombie head prop. Then he licks the propmaster himself. It's delightful."{{cite web|url=http://mentalfloss.com/article/79393/traceroute-documentary-about-nerds-and-annihilation|title=Traceroute, A Documentary about Nerds and Annihilation|date=1 May 2016|publisher=|accessdate=31 August 2018}} Pop culture magazine [[Boing Boing]] calls Traceroute "a brilliantly careening biography of a highly enigmatic species. [...] Traceroute is radical individual empiricism, a narrative biographical puzzle and an experimental projection matrix. Despite continual stimulus satiation, it is wonderful fun: the film tickles the synapses with a perfectly mixed cocktail of collectively shared context and quirkiness."{{cite web|url=http://boingboing.net/2016/04/14/the-story-of-traceroute-about.html|title=The story of Traceroute, about a Leitnerd's quest|date=14 April 2016|publisher=|accessdate=31 August 2018}} Patrick Lichty of net culture magazine [[Furtherfield]] calls it "magical (...) After watching Traceroute, I was left with a real exhilaration and a deeply reflective feeling at once. (...) What Traceroute reveals is the tradition of alterity just beneath the surface of Western culture, and that it has a powerful effect on our mass consciousness, whether it is in plain sight or not."{{cite web|url=http://www.furtherfield.org/features/reviews/traceroute-%E2%80%93-personal-journey-uncharted-depths-nerd-culture|title=Patrick Lichty, Furtherfield; March 11, 2016|publisher=|accessdate=31 August 2018}} Felix Knoke of [[Engadget]] Germany writes: "For me it is the best nerd documentary I've seen so far. Simply for the fact that it doesn't take itself as deadly serious as the other ones. (...) Traceroute deserves high praise because it represents an old-school definition of nerd culture, one that is never compatible with fintech, unicorn and iGod."{{cite web|url=http://de.engadget.com/2016/03/23/traceroute-nerd-doku-kommt-nach-deutschland/|title=Traceroute: Nerd-Doku kommt nach Deutschland|publisher=|accessdate=31 August 2018}} Pop culture critic Thomas Kaestle comments: "Traceroute is game, challenge, encyclopedia, and sentimental journey all in one. As a documentary it is most skillfully composed. And as a narration it is highly compatible. This film will, in passing, sweep proclaimed nerds off their feet. And it will touch the hearts of those who still need some explanation."{{cite web|url=http://www.zebrabutter.net/traceroute-unterwegs-mit-dem-leitnerd.html|title=Thomas Kaestle on Zebrabutter, January 13, 2016|publisher=|accessdate=31 August 2018}} ''Diamond in the Rough Films'' praises Grenzfurthner's hosting and storytelling: "This doc works in some very unconventional ways, not the least of which is our plucky protagonist. Grenzfurthner is an absolute charmer as our host and his narration is note-perfect (the accent is so cool in that Werner Herzog kind of way). It's really rare in a documentary about a not-that-famous person where you become almost instantly won-over and invested in their personal journey."{{cite web|url=http://www.ditrfilms.com/#!traceroute/hvlta|title=ditrfilms|website=ditrfilms|accessdate=31 August 2018}} Blogger and sci-fiction author [[Cory Doctorow]] states about Traceroute that "Johannes is a brilliant lunatic of surpassing and delightful weirdness."{{cite web|url=https://vimeo.com/ondemand/traceroute|title=Watch Traceroute Online - Vimeo On Demand|first=|last=monochrom|date=27 November 2015|publisher=|accessdate=31 August 2018|via=Vimeo}} MicroFilmmaker Magazine writes: "The different people Grenzfurthner chatted with were genuinely interesting and the organic way he moved from place to place was intriguing. [...] You'll find that you've learned an awful lot about technology, nerdiness, and America."{{cite web|url=http://www.microfilmmaker.com/2016/04/traceroute_ssr/|title=Traceroute (Straight Shooter Film Review) - MicroFilmmaker Magazine|website=www.microfilmmaker.com|accessdate=31 August 2018}} Richard Propes (The Independent Critic) writes: "It's challenging. It's thought-provoking. It's remarkably honest. It's well researched. [...] If you're expecting nothing more than your usual nerd doc with its cosplay cuteness and asocial gamers, you're going to be not just disappointed but probably traumatized. Grenzfurthner is clearly full-on willing to challenge culture, stereotypes, accepted thoughts and just about everything else. There's a healthy dose of sexuality in Traceroute, which one might expect, yet Grenzfurthner also immerses the film in politics, activism and social shifts. [...] Refreshingly devoid of the pretentiousness so often found amongst truly intellectual films, Traceroute is simultaneously a pretty wonderful personal journey and an immensely satisfying cinematic experience."{{cite web|url=http://theindependentcritic.com/traceroute|title=The Independent Critic - "Traceroute" Set for World Premiere on April 28th at NYC Independent Film Festival|website=theindependentcritic.com|accessdate=31 August 2018}} ===Awards=== The film won ''Best Documentary Feature'' at the 2016 ''Phuture Con Festival'' (Denver, USA/Sapporo, Japan),{{cite web|url=http://phuturecon.com|title=Phuturecon|website=Nandalow|accessdate=31 August 2018}} won the ''Award of Merit'' for Documentary Feature at the 2016 ''Accolade Global Film Competition'',{{cite web|url=http://accoladecompetition.org/past-winners/awards-of-merit-march-2016/|title=Awards of Merit March 2016 -|website=accoladecompetition.org|accessdate=31 August 2018}} won the award for ''Best Documentary Feature Film'' at the 2016 ''Subversive Film Awards'' in Los Angeles,[http://subversivecinemasociety.com/awards.html List of winners of 2016 Subversive Film Awards in Los Angeles] won the ''Award of Merit'' at ''[[Indie Fest|The Indie Fest Awards]]'' in several categories (Documentary Feature, History / Biographical, Tourism / Travel, Contemporary Issues / Awareness Raising){{cite web|url=http://theindiefest.com/past-winners/award-of-merit-may-2016/|title=Award of Merit May 2016|website=theindiefest.com|accessdate=31 August 2018}} and won a ''Honorable Mention'' at ''The Indie Gathering International Film Festival 2016''.{{cite web|url=http://www.theindiegathering.com|title=Welcome Page - The International Indie Gathering|website=www.theindiegathering.com|accessdate=31 August 2018}} It was nominated for the 2016 ''Austrian Documentary Award (ADA)''.{{cite web|url=http://www.ethnocineca.at/en/pagelayouts/awards/ada/|title=ADA: ethnocineca|website=www.ethnocineca.at|accessdate=31 August 2018}} The [[hackerspace]] ''Voidwarranties'' in [[Antwerp]], [[Belgium]] awarded ''Traceroute'' the title of "Nerd Movie Of The Year 2016".{{cite web|url=http://monochrom.at/blog/index.php?op=ViewArticle&articleId=2672&blogId=1|title=Traceroute: Winner Nerd Movie Of The Year 2016 at Voidwarranties - monochrom|website=monochrom.at|accessdate=31 August 2018}} Traceroute is a competition finalist at the 2016 ''Filmmatic Filmmaker Awards''.{{cite web|url=http://filmmaticawards.org/2016-winners/4592931789|title=Filmmatic Filmmaker Awards 2016, Winners|publisher=|accessdate=31 August 2018}} ''Diamond In The Rough Film Festival'' 2016 in [[Cupertino]] awarded Traceroute ''Best Feature Documentary'',{{cite web|url=http://www.ditrfilms.com/2016-ditr-film-festival|title=2016 DITR Film Festival - HOME|website=ditrfilms|accessdate=31 August 2018}} ''Celludroid Film Festival 2016'' in [[Cape Town]] awarded the film ''Best Documentary''{{cite web|url=http://celludroid.net/|title=CELLUDROID Sci-Fi / Anime / Fantasy Film Festival|website=celludroid.net|accessdate=31 August 2018}} and ''FrackFest'' 2016 in Oklahoma City gave Traceroute the ''Best of the Fest'' award and the ''Best Doc of the Fest'' Award.{{cite web|url=http://frackfest.org/|title=Frack Fest OKC's Underground Multimedia Fest|website=Frack Fest OKC's Underground Multimedia Fest|accessdate=31 August 2018}} The film is also semi-finalist for the Golden Kapok Award at [[Guangzhou International Documentary Film Festival]] 2016.{{cite web|url=http://monochrom.at/blog/index.php?op=ViewArticle&articleId=2728&blogId=1|title=Traceroute is in the semi-finals of GZDOC - monochrom|website=monochrom.at|accessdate=31 August 2018}} Johannes Grenzfurthner's editing was nominated for "Best Editing" at the 2017 Filmplus Festival, Cologne, Germany.{{cite web|url=http://www.filmplus.de/vornominierungen-80.html|title=Vornominierungen - Filmplus – Festival für Filmschnitt und Montagekunst|website=www.filmplus.de|accessdate=31 August 2018}} ==Sequel== In a 2016 interview with [[Film Threat]]'s [[Chris Gore]], Johannes Grenzfurthner debated the possibility of a sequel, a trip to destinations in Eastern Europe, with the goal to drive from [[Vienna]] to [[Baikonur Cosmodrome]]. Grenzfurthner changed the concept and created [[Glossary of Broken Dreams]] (2018), which he considers a loose sequel or follow-up.{{cite web|url=https://www.zebrabutter.net/der-film-glossary-of-broken-dreams-oder-im-schlachthaus-zum-goldenen-kalb.html|title=Zebrabutter: "Der Film Glossary of Broken Dreams oder: Im Schlachthaus Zum Goldenen Kalb"; April 25, 2018|publisher=|accessdate=31 August 2018}}{{cite web|url=http://www.monochrom.at/glossary|title=monochrom: GLOSSARY OF BROKEN DREAMS|website=www.monochrom.at|accessdate=31 August 2018}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb title|id=4490762|title=Traceroute}} *[http://www.monochrom.at/traceroute/ Official homepage] *[http://www.vimeo.com/monochrom/traceroute-trailer/ Traceroute trailer] *[https://vimeo.com/ondemand/traceroute Traceroute, film download, Vimeo On Demand] {{DEFAULTSORT:Traceroute}} [[Category:2016 films]] [[Category:American road movies]] [[Category:2010s road movies]] [[Category:2010s documentary films]] [[Category:2010s independent films]] [[Category:Austrian comedy films]] [[Category:Austrian films]] [[Category:Austrian satirical films]] [[Category:Austrian independent films]] [[Category:American documentary films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American independent films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Films about technological impact]] [[Category:Autobiographical documentary films]] [[Category:Documentary films about fandom]] [[Category:Documentary films about the Internet]] [[Category:Documentary films about philosophy]] [[Category:Documentary films about politics]] [[Category:Bulletin board systems]] [[Category:Cyberpunk films]] [[Category:Computing culture]] [[Category:Nerd culture]] [[Category:Hacker culture]] [[Category:DIY culture]] [[Category:Science fiction fandom]] [[Category:Middle class culture]] [[Category:Sexuality and computing]] [[Category:Monochrom]] [[Category:Internet culture]] [[Category:Internet documentary films]]
